CGSC 481.descr: Programming techniques for problems not amenable to algorithmic solutions. Problem formulation, search strategies, state spaces, applications of logic, knowledge representation, planning and application areas.
CGSC 481.preReq: CISC 220 with a minimum grade of C-, CISC 304.
CGSC 481.restrict: Students who received credit in CISC681 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CGSC 485.name: Seminar in Cognitive Science
CGSC 485.descr: Intensive interdisciplinary study of topics in linguistics & cognitive science. Allows students to synthesize what they have learned in previous coursework by bringing together divergent methodologies and applying them to topics in cognitive psychology, speech-language pathology, mind & language, science of language, and philosphical aspects of cognitive science.&nbsp;
CGSC 485.restrict: May be repeated for credit as topic changes.

CGSC 490.name: Philosophy of Language
CGSC 490.descr: Traditional scientific and philosophical issues associated with theories of meaning and reference of language.

CGSC 496.name: Psycholinguistics
CGSC 496.descr: An introduction to psycholinguistics, the study of the psychological processing of linguistic information at the levels of speech sounds, words, memory, sentences and meaning.

CMLT 207.name: Great Writers of the Western World I: 1100-1700
CMLT 207.descr: Studies writers such as Dante, Chaucer, Rabelais and Cervantes, in translation.
CMLT 207.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

CMLT 208.name: Great Writers of the Western World II: 1650-1950
CMLT 208.descr: Studies writers such as Moliere, Voltaire, Goethe, Dostoevski, Thomas Mann and Herman Hesse, in translation.
CMLT 208.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

CMLT 217.name: Introduction to Film
CMLT 217.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

CMLT 218.name: Introduction to Drama
CMLT 218.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

CMLT 219.name: Introduction to the Novel
CMLT 219.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

CMLT 316.name: Classical Mythology: Gods, Heroes, and Monsters
CMLT 316.descr: Cosmological myths and heroic sagas in the literature and art of Greece and Rome. The influence of the mythology in later art and literature.
CMLT 316.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

CMLT 317.name: Film History
CMLT 317.descr: History of American or various foreign national cinemas.
CMLT 317.restrict: May be repeated for credit when topics vary.
CMLT 317.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

CMLT 318.name: Studies in Film
CMLT 318.descr: Close study of film genres, major directors, and other topics.
CMLT 318.restrict: May be taken up to three times when topics vary.
CMLT 318.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

CMLT 320.name: Varying Authors and Genres
CMLT 320.descr: Cultural, especially cross-cultural and/or interdisciplinary studies with primary emphasis on the aesthetic context of the announced topic, e.g., Nordic Saga and Myth; Courtly Love; and the European Postwar Novel.
CMLT 320.restrict: May be repeated for credit when topics vary.
CMLT 320.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

CMLT 321.name: Medieval Literature and Culture
CMLT 321.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

CMLT 322.name: Topics: Classical Literature in Translation
CMLT 322.descr: Special topics in Greek and Roman culture and civilization. Particular areas and writers to be announced, e.g., ancient epic, ancient drama, Greek literature in translation.
CMLT 322.restrict: May be repeated for credit when topics vary.
CMLT 322.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

CMLT 330.name: Topics: World Literatures and Cultures
CMLT 330.descr: Cultural, especially cross-cultural, study with primary emphasis on the historical development of the announced area, e.g., Nature in the Ancient World, Speculative Fiction, Transformation of a Myth. See Courses Search for topics.
CMLT 330.restrict: May be repeated three times for credit when topics vary.
CMLT 330.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

CMLT 341.name: Theatre/Drama: Classic/Medieval
CMLT 341.descr: Survey of major historical and theoretical developments in theatre practice and dramaturgy during the period. Readings in primary and secondary historical sources, major critical and theoretical texts, and representative plays of the period.
CMLT 341.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

CMLT 361.name: Studies in Literary Criticism and Theory
CMLT 361.descr: Study of problems in textual interpretation and aesthetics from the ancient world through the present, with attention to both the principal movements in critical theory and the social and philosophical contexts of interpretation. Content varies by expertise of instructor.
CMLT 361.restrict: May be taken up to three times when topics vary.

CMLT 385.name: Studies in Literary Criticism and Theory
CMLT 385.descr: Studies in selected topics in literary criticism and critical theory.
CMLT 385.restrict: May be taken up to three times when topics vary.

COMM 200.name: Topics in Communication
COMM 200.descr: Rotating topics presenting overviews of social science research on communication in various contexts including the behavior of individuals,relationships, social groups, and media in society. Emphasize theories, empirical findings, and applications of communication research in the social and behavioral sciences.
COMM 200.restrict: May be repeated two times for nine credits when topics vary.
COMM 200.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 204.name: Gender and Communication
COMM 204.descr: Deals with gender differences in communication in varied contexts, such as conflict, marriage, family, friendship, and work.
COMM 204.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 206.name: Sex, Violence, and the Media
COMM 206.descr: Examine the issues surrounding the prevalence of sex and violence in the media. Topics include free speech/press decisions and their impact, why people watch, the possible effects, and the market forces that encourage corporations to carry such content.
COMM 206.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 212.name: Public Speaking & Professional Presentation
COMM 212.descr: Includes an analysis of the types and principles of the communication inherent in the business and professional setting; a concentration upon the development of presentational skills: analyzing audiences, questioning, interviewing, researching, supporting, organizing and delivering information; an opportunity to develop and present materials within dyads, small groups and public contexts.
COMM 212.restrict: Students who have received credit in COMM 350 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

COMM 223.name: Sports, Media, and Culture
COMM 223.descr: This course examines the interrelationship of sports, media, and culture in today’s society and how that interrelationship sometimes reinforces or challenge social values. It draws on the cultural identification of class, race, and gender to identify sports values and cultural values. Drawing on theories of culture, rhetoric, and social criticism, we will examine media’s role in telling the story of sports and, in telling that story, shapes cultural values. Students will study several critical approaches to sports and public discourse and will apply those approaches to journalism, public relations, the news and popular media, and other forms of mass communication.
COMM 223.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 227.name: Family Communication
COMM 227.descr: Introduces students to the area of family communication. Gain knowledge about basic theories of family communication and learn to apply theories and research to real-world contexts.
COMM 227.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 228.name: Introduction to Organizational Communication
COMM 228.descr: The course will help students develop organizational communication knowledge, skills, and abilities to empower students to become more effective organizational members and leaders. This course is an introduction to research and theories on communication within organizations.
COMM 228.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 230.name: Communication and Interpersonal Behavior
COMM 230.descr: Introduces key principles of interpersonal communication and discusses their application across diverse contexts.
COMM 230.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 245.name: Media and Society
COMM 245.descr: The relationship between media and culture; how media affect culture (i.e., socialization and role modeling); and exploration of new forms of mass communication.
COMM 245.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 256.name: Philosophy of Communication
COMM 256.descr: This course discusses the philosophical traditions and ways of knowing that underlie and inform communication theory and scholarship.
COMM 256.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

COMM 263.name: Communicative Behavior and Culture
COMM 263.descr: Communicative processes in other cultures as well as subcultures in the US will be discussed. Students will become more mindful and aware of their own cultural patterns as well. Difficulties in cross cultural communication will also be discussed.

COMM 284.name: Gender, Culture and Digital Media
COMM 284.descr: Explores the relationship between gender, culture, and digital media.
COMM 284.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

COMM 301.name: Introduction to Communication Research Methods
COMM 301.descr: The conceptual bases of research methodology: formulating questions, designing, conducting and analyzing research.

COMM 305.name: Topics: Communication and Politics
COMM 305.descr: Topics vary and focus on significant areas of political communication with an emphasis on content, trends, processes, theories, and effects. Topics may include political entertainment, news, political advertising and campaigning, ethics, public opinion, or audience research.
COMM 305.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 306.name: Digital Technology in Politics
COMM 306.descr: Focuses on how technology influences and is used in political campaigns, public policy debates, governance, and public opinion, as well as how politics shapes technological development, processes, and policy. Special attention given to synergy among political actors, media, non-governmental organizations and citizens in shaping, consuming, and producing communication technology and policy.

COMM 309.name: Introduction to Public Relations
COMM 309.descr: Examination of the public relations process, practices and principles in various settings, including corporations, non-profit organizations, educational institutions and government. Insights are gained through case studies and interviews with public relations professionals.

COMM 311.name: Public Relations Writing
COMM 311.descr: Development of writing skills with emphasis on clarity, conciseness, color, organization and flow. Application of skills in various public relations formats (news releases, features, profiles, brochures, etc.) geared to specific audiences and appropriate channels.

COMM 313.name: Communication Principles in Advertising
COMM 313.descr: Provides a comprehensive overview of the marketing function, emphasizing integrated marketing communication. Includes historical perspective and current advertising and promotion principles and practices. Combines both individual and small team projects, such as developing an Integrated Marketing Communication campaign.

COMM 318.name: Topics in Media Communication
COMM 318.descr: Focus on introductory areas of study in mass communication.
COMM 318.restrict: May be repeated two times for nine credits when topics vary.

COMM 323.name: Topics in Journalism Production
COMM 323.descr: Experiential education involving broadcast and production topics.

COMM 324.name: Electronic Media Production
COMM 324.descr: Foundational concepts and skills to be built upon in subsequent courses in broadcast production/broadcast news sequences. Introduction to program content planning, writing for visual media, studio equipment, field equipment, and non-linear editing.
COMM 324.restrict: Serves as suggested prerequisite for COMM 326, COMM 388, and COMM 426 (News Documentary).

COMM 325.name: Studio Television Production
COMM 325.descr: Television as a mass communication media. Background, programming, production and studio procedures in educational television, broadcasting and closed circuit. Laboratory observation and practices.

COMM 326.name: Field Television Production
COMM 326.descr: Students gain practical knowledge of field television news production and utilize this knowledge to conceptualize, shoot, write, and edit videos, while working on a production deadline.

COMM 329.name: Broadcast Newswriting
COMM 329.descr: Emphasizes broadcast newswriting fundamentals and comparisons to other forms of writing. Includes news judgment, news gathering, and news editing, as well as integration of current events.
COMM 329.restrict: COMM and COMI majors not minoring in JOUR.

COMM 333.name: Social Media Management
COMM 333.descr: Explore strategic communication through social media. Experience a highly interactive classroom exploring differences between personal use and marketers’ uses of social media. Students complete multiple digital projects both in-class and out of class. Topics include marketing, public relations, audience analysis, demographics, metrics, digital engagement, interactivity, return-on-investment, scheduling, and digital monitoring through readings, videos, projects and case studies.

COMM 337.name: Topics in Political Communication
COMM 337.descr: This lecture series focuses on various thematic issues in political communication and campaign politics.
COMM 337.restrict: May be repeated twice for credit.

COMM 340.name: Politics and the Media
COMM 340.descr: Political roles of the media in socialization, political competence, agenda setting, the electoral process and political crises. Emphasis on media-political system interaction and its import in a democratic society.

COMM 341.name: Theories of Interpersonal Communication
COMM 341.descr: Survey of concepts and theories in interpersonal communication. Focuses on dyadic interaction and relationships as created, maintained, and modified through verbal and nonverbal behavior.
COMM 341.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 343.name: Topics in Interpersonal Communication
COMM 343.descr: Focuses on introductory areas of study in interpersonal communication.
COMM 343.restrict: May be repeated three times for credit when topics vary.

COMM 345.name: Legal Issues of the Mass Media
COMM 345.descr: Survey of legal issues affecting the development and performance of the mass media. The foundation of American communications law outlined through the study of First Amendment theory, its origin and development. Legal issues concerning libel, obscenity, copyright and broadcast regulation discussed.

COMM 350.name: Public Speaking
COMM 350.descr: Analyzes and applies theory and research in public speaking. Develops skills in preparation, presentation and evaluation of speeches. Includes classroom performances.

COMM 364.name: Internship
COMM 364.descr: Practical, on-the-job training in the student’s field of interest: i.e., interpersonal, mass media, public relations or organizational communication.
COMM 364.restrict: Offered in spring and fall semesters only. Open to junior and senior communication majors only. May be repeated 1 time for a maximum of 6 credits.

COMM 370.name: Theories of Media Communication
COMM 370.descr: An examination of the foundations and development of theories of mass communication. Specific areas of study include media, society and the individual, media violence, cultivation theory, personal influence, social learning theory, diffusion theory and general media effects.
COMM 370.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 388.name: Video Production Practicum
COMM 388.descr: Involves intensive work on specific productions. Includes practice in various aspects of video production: development, direction, management, production, and editing.
COMM 388.restrict: Requires permission of instructor. May be repeated for eight credits.

COMM 408.name: New Media Project Development
COMM 408.descr: Application of communication research processes to designing new media (e.g.,web sites, streaming video, electronic communication, interactive media) for aclient.  Involves conducting research for planning, developing strategies,designing prototypes, and making recommendations for implementation andevaluation.

COMM 409.name: Public Relations Campaign Planning
COMM 409.descr: Comprehensive recap of the Integrated Marketing Communication function, with anemphasis on public relations research, objectives, strategies, integratedtactics, and campaign evaluation.  Utilizes a small team “service learning”setup, wherein the teams adopt a community non-profit organization and workclosely with Board and staff members to produce and present a comprehensivepublic relations campaign plan.

COMM 413.name: Public Relations Management
COMM 413.descr: Focuses on case studies and tactics that public relations practitioners need to know in corporate, non-profit, government, education, agency, entertainment, or media settings.  Includes a strong emphasis on social media and e-portfolio development.

COMM 414.name: Topics in American Politics
COMM 414.descr: Contemporary topics in American government and politics.

COMM 417.name: Communication and the Management of Conflict
COMM 417.descr: An overview of communication and the conflict process in face-to-faceinteraction.  Emphasis on theories concerning the structure, analysis, andmanagement of conflict situations.

COMM 418.name: Advanced Topics in Media Communication
COMM 418.descr: Current directions in mass communication theory and practice including new technologies, politics, broadcast programming and research, advertising and audience responses to media content.
COMM 418.restrict: Not open to COMI majors. May be repeated three times for credit when topics vary.

COMM 421.name: Intercultural Communication
COMM 421.descr: Enhances students’ understanding of cultures, communication and intercultural communication processes. In addition, communicative strategies for improving intercultural communication is discussed.
COMM 421.restrict: Some sections offered in Madrid, Spain and Costa Rica.

COMM 423.name: Communication, Advertising, and the Consumer
COMM 423.descr: Introduction to the content of advertising, including portrayals of gender, race and sexuality. Investigate the relationship between advertising and the individual consumer, particularly what advertising cognitive effects can be and how they may result in behavioral effects.

COMM 424.name: Media Message Analysis
COMM 424.descr: Examination of methodology used to study media content and effects.  Focus on past and ongoing research in broadcast, nonbroadcast and print media.  Method of how to conduct and assess research relating to mass media.

COMM 425.name: Advanced Topics in Politics and Broadcast Journalism
COMM 425.descr: Topics vary and may include influence of crisis news on national and international politics, effectiveness of political documentaries and ethical and historical underpinnings of broadcast journalism.
COMM 425.restrict: Not open to COMI majors. May be repeated for nine credits when topics vary. When topic is News Documentary, COMM 324 suggested prerequisite.

COMM 426.name: Broadcast News Documentary
COMM 426.descr: Use the format of a news documentary to explore current issues and topics affecting society. Select a topic and spend the semester producing a documentary. Understand and perfect TV production skills, including writing, interviewing, shooting and editing.
COMM 426.restrict: May be repeated once for credit.

COMM 427.name: Broadcast News
COMM 427.descr: Communication students learn the pressures and standards of broadcast newswhile writing and producing a scheduled studio TV program.  Emphasis on writingnews for broadcast, program story-selection issues, video selection,interviewing techniques, professionalism. Students produce a weekly newsprogram in the lab.

COMM 440.name: Topics in Interpersonal Communication
COMM 440.descr: Topics vary and focus on significant areas of theory and research in interpersonal communication. Topics may include nonverbal communication, lifespan communication and communication in intimate relationships.
COMM 440.restrict: May be repeated three times for credit when topics vary.

COMM 442.name: Topics in Organizational Communication
COMM 442.descr: Focuses on significant areas of theory and research in organizational communication. Topics may include gender, communication, or interpersonal relations in organizations, such as superior/subordinate relationships.
COMM 442.restrict: May be repeated for up to nine credits when topics vary.

COMM 443.name: Communication and Emotion
COMM 443.descr: Introduces students to the role emotion plays in interpersonal communication and how communication influences our feelings. The course presents students with skill building exercises and writing assignments that are designed to put what they learn in the classroom into action in the real world.

COMM 444.name: Global Agenda
COMM 444.descr: Seminar survey of current geopolitical problems facing the US government and global news media.  Guest lecturers and practitioners in diplomacy and the international media explore the problems, US foreign policy and media influence upon both.
COMM 444.restrict: May be repeated for credit when topics vary.

COMM 446.name: Special Topics in Public Relations
COMM 446.descr: Overviews of public relations theory and practice in various contexts including research, ethics, diversity, writing, planning, execution and management.

COMM 447.name: National Agenda
COMM 447.descr: Seminar offered in conjunction with speaker series focused on current policy and political problems facing the United States. Guest lecturers, office holders and candidates, political and media practitioners explore the problems and their implications for the nation and for campaigns and decision making.
COMM 447.restrict: Students must be Juniors or Seniors and need permission of the instructor to enroll.

COMM 450.name: Media Effects
COMM 450.descr: Examines history and nature of research on effects of mass media, particularly television, in such areas as attitude change, socialization, role modeling and sex and violence.

COMM 452.name: Communication and Persuasion
COMM 452.descr: An examination of how influence is created and resisted through communication in various settings, including personal relationships, public relations, advertising and political campaigns. Emphasis on contemporary theories of persuasion and attitude change, with applications to the various content areas studied.

COMM 453.name: Health Communication
COMM 453.descr: This course examines theories and methods for studying relationships between media and health. Topics include media portrayals of health issues; public engagements with health information and technologies; and the role of media in health promotion.

COMM 454.name: Children and the Media
COMM 454.descr: Media research and theory as they relate to children. Substantive areas include children’s use and comprehension of media, content of children’s television programming, television and the family, children and advertising and the media’s contribution to social values and roles.

COMM 456.name: Communication in Organizations
COMM 456.descr: Introduction to concepts and research related to communication processes in organizational settings. Both traditional and interpretive approaches are emphasized.

COMM 458.name: Science Communication
COMM 458.descr: This course examines how scientists communicate with journalists and citizens; how news and entertainment media present science and scientists; how messages about science shape public perceptions; and how citizens engage with scientific issues.

COMM 468.name: Undergraduate Research in Communication
COMM 468.descr: Undergraduate research in area of communication conducted on or off campus, out of class, and under supervision of faculty member.
COMM 468.restrict: Open to junior and senior communication majors only. Requires permission of instructor.

COMM 476.name: Social Media and Communication
COMM 476.descr: Focus on how and why people use social media.  Various social media platforms will be explored and their effect on communicative processes will be examined.

COMM 485.name: Analysis of Face-to-Face Communication
COMM 485.descr: An examination of methods for analyzing face-to-face interaction, messageconstruction, and message interpretation.

COMM 486.name: Multimedia Literacy
COMM 486.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

COMM 490.name: Honors Capstone
COMM 490.descr: A capstone experience for Communication Honors majors.

CSCD 490.name: Research Practicum
CSCD 490.descr: Research experience in Communication Sciences and Disorders.

CISC 101.name: Principles of Computing
CISC 101.descr: Introduces students to the central ideas of computing and computer science including programs, algorithms, abstraction, the internet, and information systems. Instills ideas and practices of computational thinking and engages students in activities that show how computing and computer science change the world. Explores computing as a creative activity and empowers students to apply computational thinking to all disciplines including the arts, humanities, business, social and physical sciences, health, and entertainment.
CISC 101.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

CISC 103.name: Introduction to Computer Science with Web Applications
CISC 103.descr: Principles of computer science illustrated through programming in scripting languages such as JavaScript and VBScript. Topics include control structures, arrays, functions, and procedures. Programming projects illustrate web-based applications.
CISC 103.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

CISC 106.name: General Computer Science for Engineers
CISC 106.descr: Principles of computer science illustrated and applied through programming in a general-purpose language. Programming projects illustrate computational problems, styles, and issues that arise in engineering.
CISC 106.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

CISC 108.name: Introduction to Computer Science I
CISC 108.descr: Computing and principles of programming with an emphasis on systematic program design. Topics include functional programming, data abstraction, procedural abstraction, use of control and state, recursion, testing, and object-oriented programming concepts. Requires no prior programming experience, open to any major, but intended primarily for majors and minors in computer science or mathematics.
CISC 108.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

CISC 181.name: Introduction to Computer Science II
CISC 181.descr: Principles of computer science illustrated and applied through programming in an object oriented language. Programming projects illustrate computational problems, styles and issues that arise in computer systems development and in all application areas of computation.
CISC 181.preReq: Grade of C- or better in CISC 108 or CISC 106.
CISC 181.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

CISC 187.name: Vertically Integrated Projects I
CISC 187.descr: The Vertically-Integrated Projects (VIP) Program operates in a research and development context. Undergraduate students that join VIP teams earn academic credit for their participation in design/discovery efforts that assist faculty and graduate students with research and development issues in their areas of expertise.

CISC 210.name: Introduction to Systems Programming
CISC 210.preReq: A grade of C- or better in CISC 106 or CISC 108.

CISC 220.name: Data Structures
CISC 220.descr: Review of data type abstraction, recursion, arrays, stacks, queues, multiple stacks and linked lists. Emphasis on dynamic storage management, garbage collection, trees, graphs, tables, sorting and searching.
CISC 220.preReq: A minimum grade of C- in CISC 210.

CISC 250.name: Business Telecommunication Networks
CISC 250.descr: Examines technologies of information transmission currently utilized in the business environments and the implications of these technologies upon the development and implementation of information systems. Provides a basic background in the convergence of voice, data and video services into common digital networks. Security issues also considered.

CISC 260.name: Machine Organization and Assembly Language
CISC 260.descr: Introduction to the basics of machine organization. Programming tools and techniques at the machine and assembly levels. Assembly language programming and computer arithmetic techniques.
CISC 260.preReq: A minimum grade of C- in CISC 210.

CISC 275.name: Introduction to Software Engineering
CISC 275.descr: Object oriented software design and development through use of an object oriented programming language. Topics include team programming, design patterns, graphical user interfaces, software engineering tools (e.g., integrated development environments, version control, build management, bug tracking, automated testing).
CISC 275.preReq: Minimum grade of C- in CISC 181 and CISC 220.

CISC 287.name: Vertically Integrated Projects II
CISC 287.descr: The Vertically-Integrated Projects (VIP) Program operates in a research and development context. Undergraduate students that join VIP teams earn academic credit for their participation in design/discovery efforts that assist faculty and graduate students with research and development issues in their areas of expertise.

CISC 303.name: Automata Theory
CISC 303.descr: Automata and formal language theory. Background for advanced applications in compilers, computer networks, operating systems, and natural language processing. Finite automata and regular languages. Push down automata and context free grammars. Turing machines.
CISC 303.preReq: A minimum grade of C- in both MATH 210 and CISC 220.

CISC 304.name: Logic for Programming
CISC 304.descr: Propositional and predicate logic for general reasoning and advanced applications in knowledge representation in artificial intelligence and database, program correctness and programming semantics. Models, resolution, logic programming, and natural deduction.
CISC 304.preReq: CISC 220, MATH 210 (with minimum C- grade in both).

CISC 320.name: Introduction to Algorithms
CISC 320.descr: Design and analysis of algorithms: worst/average case analysis, proofs for correctness and performance of algorithms. Algorithmic strategies (divide and conquer, greedy methods, dynamic programming, etc.). Algorithms for searching, forming and traversal of strings, trees and graphs. Categorization of computational problems: classes P and NP. NP completeness.
CISC 320.preReq: MATH 210 and a minimum grade of C- in CISC 220.

CISC 355.name: Computers, Ethics and Society
CISC 355.restrict: Cannot be used as a technical elective for CISC or INSY majors or minors.
CISC 355.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

CISC 356.name: Intellectual Property in the Digital Age
CISC 356.descr: Explore economic, philosophical, social, and technical approaches to intellectual property (1500 BCE to present) then will research contemporary IP issues in software, entertainment, the Internet, and biotechnology.
CISC 356.restrict: Junior or Senior standing. Cannot be used as a technical elective for CISC or INSY majors or minors.
CISC 356.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

CISC 357.name: Engaging Youth in Computing
CISC 357.preReq: CISC 101 or CISC 103 or CISC 106 or CISC 108.
CISC 357.restrict: Student must have sufficient time in their schedule to visit schools weekly between 9am and 3pm. Students must pass a background check that clears them for teaching. Cannot be used as a technical elective by CISC or INSY majors.

CISC 360.name: Computer Architecture
CISC 360.descr: Principles and techniques used in the architecture of digital computers. Machine elements and their interrelation. Instruction sets, risc vs cisc, registers, busses and switches.
CISC 360.preReq: A minimum grade of C- in CISC 220 and CISC 260 (or equivalent courses).

CISC 361.name: Operating Systems
CISC 361.descr: Principles and techniques employed in the development of operating systems and their control programs. Includes management of memory, processors, I/O devices.
CISC 361.preReq: A minimum grade of C- in both CISC 220 and CISC 260. CPEG 222 may be substituted for CISC 260.

CISC 372.name: Parallel Computing
CISC 372.descr: Introduction to parallel computing concepts, methodologies, and tools. Programming and algorithmic techniques for code that will run simultaneously on parallel computing architectures. Topics include: single and multi-core parallelism, shared and distributed memory architectures, concurrency, program decomposition, data distribution, communication, load balancing, scalability, locality, granularity, debugging, performance evaluation.
CISC 372.preReq: C- or better in both CISC 220 and CISC 260.

CISC 374.name: Educational Game Development
CISC 374.descr: Experience the software engineering process through creating educational games for youth; open-ended, project-oriented team learning while assisting regional teachers in integrating computing and computational thinking into the classroom; interact with teachers as clients, hone communication skills and experience design-studio-based critiques of your ideas.

CISC 387.name: Vertically Integrated Projects III
CISC 387.descr: The Vertically-Integrated Projects (VIP) Program operates in a research and development context. Undergraduate students that join VIP teams earn academic credit for their participation in design/discovery efforts that assist faculty and graduate students with research and development issues in their areas of expertise.

CISC 401.name: Elements of the Theory of Computation
CISC 401.descr: General models of computation, formal languages and automata theory and algorithmic unsolvability.
CISC 401.restrict: Students who received credit in CISC601 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CISC 404.name: Logic in Computer Science
CISC 404.descr: Formal introduction to first-order logic with emphasis on its relevance to computer science. Syntax, semantics, models, formal proofs and results on soundness, consistency, completeness, compactness and undecidability. Automated theorem proving also covered.
CISC 404.restrict: Students who received credit in CISC604 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CISC 410.name: Computational Mathematics I
CISC 410.descr: Floating point numbers; conditioning and stability; LU, Cholesky, and QR factorizations; square and overdetermined linear systems; Newton and quasi- Newton rootfinding methods; piecewise polynomials for interpolation, integration, and finite differences; explicit methods for initial-value problems. Prerequisites: MATH 305, MATH 349, or MATH 351. Students may not receive credit for both MATH 353 and MATH 426.
CISC 410.restrict: Requires familiarity with computing (e.g., programming language).

CISC 411.name: Computational Mathematics II
CISC 411.descr: Eigenvalue and singular-value decompositions; power and Krylov subspace iterations; global interpolation and quadrature; methods for boundary-value problems and Poisson’s equation; implicit solvers for stiff problems; method of lines for partial differential equations; diffusion and advection problems.

CISC 414.name: Formal Methods in Software Engineering
CISC 414.descr: Formal approaches to the specification, verification, and design of software systems. Topics include representing programs as transition systems; liveness and safety properties; state space reachability; explicit, symbolic and automata-based model checking; temporal logics; symbolic execution; automated theorem-proving; and relational calculus. Learn to use state-of-the-art tools based on these methods, such as the model checker Spin.
CISC 414.preReq: CISC 304 or equivalent course, or permission of instructor.
CISC 414.restrict: Students who received credit in CISC614 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CISC 436.name: Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
CISC 436.descr: Concepts, methodologies, and tools in bioinformatics. Abstraction of biological problems for computational solutions. Genome sequencing and assembly, bio-sequence analysis and comparison and database search, dynamics programming, hidden Markov models, and phylogenetic trees.

CISC 437.name: Database Systems
CISC 437.descr: Physical and logical organization of databases. Data retrieval languages, relational database languages, security and integrity, concurrency, distributed databases.
CISC 437.preReq: A minimum grade of C- in CISC 220.
CISC 437.restrict: Students who received credit in CISC637 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CISC 440.name: Computer Graphics
CISC 440.descr: Computer graphics technology, two- and three-dimensional systems, graphics software systems, modeling and object hierarchy, and animation.
CISC 440.restrict: Students who received credit in CISC640 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CISC 442.name: Introduction to Computer Vision
CISC 442.descr: Analysis of images and video to recognize, reconstruct, model, and otherwise infer static and dynamic properties of objects in the three-dimensional world. Geometry of image formation; image processing such as smoothing, edge and feature detection, color, and texture; segmentation; shape representation including deformable templates; stereo vision; motion estimation and tracking; techniques for 3-D reconstruction; image registration methods.
CISC 442.restrict: Students who received credit in CISC642 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CISC 449.name: Topics in Computer Applications
CISC 449.descr: Contents will vary to coincide with the interests of students and current faculty.
CISC 449.restrict: Students who received credit in CISC649 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CISC 450.name: Computer Networks I
CISC 450.descr: Foundation principles, architectures and techniques employed in computer and communication networks. Focuses on mechanisms used in TCP/IP protocol suite. Topics include connection management, end-to-end reliable data transfer, sliding window protocols, quality of service, flow control, congestion control, routing, LANs, framing, error control, analog versus digital transmission, packet versus circuit switching, multiplexing.
CISC 450.restrict: Knowledge of probability and statistics recommended. Students who received credit in CISC 250, CPEG 419, CISC650, or ELEG651 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CISC 453.name: Simulation of Computer Networks
CISC 453.descr: Modeling and computer simulation of discrete systems using discrete event simulation techniques. Application to the performance evaluation and modeling of computer networks and networking protocols. Study and use of simulation systems such as OPNET, Qualnet, and ns-2.

CISC 459.name: Topics in Communications, Distributed Computing and Networks
CISC 459.descr: Contents vary to coincide with the interests of students and current faculty.
CISC 459.restrict: Students who received credit in CISC659 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CISC 464.name: Introduction to Network Security
CISC 464.descr: Practical introduction to network security field. Covers material on cryptography, intrusions, denial-of-service attacks, worms, honeynets and other hot topics in network security.

CISC 465.name: Introduction to Cybersecurity
CISC 465.descr: This cybersecurity course is an introduction to computer and network security and covers the foundation security policies and methods to provide confidentiality, integrity, and availability, as well as cryptography, auditing, and user security. Topics are reinforced with hands-on exercises run in a virtual machine environment.
CISC 465.restrict: Students who have received credit in CISC665, CPEG 465, CPEG665, ELEG 465, ELEG665, MISY 465 or MISY665 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CISC 471.name: Compiler Design
CISC 471.descr: Introduction to the design and implementation of compilers, with a focus on lexical analysis, parsing and syntax directed translation.

CISC 472.name: Web Applications Security
CISC 472.descr: This seminar-style cybersecurity course covers one specific discipline of information security known as application security. This discipline (APPSEC) refers to the development of software that can continue to function correctly even under constant scrutiny and attack by determined adversaries.
CISC 472.restrict: Programming experience in a high level language (e.g. C, C++, java, python).

CISC 473.name: Computer Science Projects
CISC 473.descr: Experimental, theoretical and literature studies of computer science problems.
CISC 473.restrict: Open to majors only. Requires permission of instructor. May be taken twice for credit when topics vary.

CISC 474.name: Advanced Web Technologies
CISC 474.descr: Programming and architecture of web servers and the technologies for implementing high performance, sophisticated web sites for applications like e-commerce. Students learn how to install and set-up a web server, how to write and install programs for a web server, and how to design and implement multi-tier client/server applications with database backends.

CISC 475.name: Advanced Software Engineering
CISC 475.descr: Understand and apply a complete modern software engineering process. Topics include requirements analysis, specification, design, implementation, verification, and project management. Real-life team projects cover all aspects of the software development lifecycle, from the requirements to acceptance testing.
CISC 475.restrict: Students who received credit in CISC675 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CISC 476.name: Secure Software Design
CISC 476.descr: This cybersecurity course introduce the theory and practices used to help make a computer program secure and provide the skills needed to implement programs that are free from vulnerabilities.
CISC 476.restrict: Programming experience in a high level language (e.g. C, C++, java, python). Graduate or upper level software course (design, etc.) recommended.

CISC 479.name: Topics in Architecture and Software
CISC 479.descr: Contents will vary to coincide with the interests of students and faculty.
CISC 479.restrict: Students who received credit in CISC679 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CISC 481.name: Artificial Intelligence
CISC 481.descr: Programming techniques for problems not amenable to algorithmic solutions. Problem formulation, search strategies, state spaces, applications of logic, knowledge representation, planning and application areas.
CISC 481.preReq: CISC 220 with a minimum grade of C-, CISC 304.
CISC 481.restrict: Students who received credit in CISC681 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CISC 482.name: Introduction to Human-Computer Interaction
CISC 482.descr: Research and theoretical methods for the study, design, implementation, and evaluation of effective user-interactive systems, including requirements for gathering, survey design, and rapid prototyping. Hands-on group projects supplement theoretical knowledge.
CISC 482.restrict: Students who received credit in CISC682 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CISC 483.name: Introduction to Data Mining
CISC 483.descr: Concepts, techniques, and algorithms for mining large data sets to discover structural patterns that can be used to make subsequent predictions. Emphasis on practical approaches and empirical evaluation. Use of a workbench of data mining tools, such as the Weka toolkit.

CISC 484.name: Introduction to Machine Learning
CISC 484.descr: Development of methods to learn to solve a task using examples. Explore different machine learning algorithms/techniques and discuss their strengths and weaknesses and situations they are or are not suited for.
CISC 484.restrict: Students who received credit in CISC684 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CISC 487.name: Vertically Integrated Projects IV
CISC 487.descr: The Vertically-Integrated Projects (VIP) Program operates in a research and development context. Undergraduate students that join VIP teams earn academic credit for their participation in design/discovery efforts that assist faculty and graduate students with research and development issues in their areas of expertise.

CISC 489.name: Topics: Artificial Intelligence
CISC 489.descr: Contents vary to coincide with the interests of students and current faculty.
CISC 489.restrict: Students who received credit in CISC689 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CISC 498.name: Computer Science Senior Design Project I
CISC 498.descr: First semester of two-semester senior software design course.  Students work in teams to develop solutions to real-world problems for a client.  Application of a modern software engineering process; requirement solicitation, analysis, and specification; prototyping; design; incremental development; testing and verification; client interaction; and presentation. Offered in Fall only.

CISC 499.name: Computer Science Senior Design Project II

CPEG 202.name: Introduction to Digital Systems
CPEG 202.descr: Analysis and design of logic circuits. Topics include: Boolean algebra and its application to switching circuits, simplification of switching functions, design of logic circuits at gate level and with MSI and LSI components. Analysis and design of synchronous and asynchronous sequential state machines.

CPEG 222.name: Microprocessor Systems
CPEG 222.descr: Introduction to microprocessors as embedded devices. Emphasizes Input/Output techniques, interrupts, real-time operation, high-level code debugging and interfacing to various types of sensors and actuators. Projects that address various embedded applications are a major part of the course.
CPEG 222.preReq: A minimum grade of C- in CPEG 202 and CISC 181 or CISC 210.

CPEG 298.name: ECE Design Challenges
CPEG 298.descr: Course includes a series of learning modules including electrical safety, use of test equipment, and interfacing microprocessors to sensors. Students complete a design assignment.

CPEG 301.name: Cybersecurity Scholars
CPEG 301.descr: The Cybersecurity Scholars Program will integrate with any major and train you to become a thought leader in cybersecurity! You will collaboratively assess the most pressing cyber-defense questions and develop both cultural and technical solutions.

CPEG 323.name: Introduction to Computer Systems Engineering
CPEG 323.descr: Studies general purpose, special purpose and embedded computer architecture. Principles of digital system design introduced including an introduction to tools for automated design and use of programmable logic devices.
CPEG 323.preReq: A minimum grade of C- in CPEG 222.

CPEG 324.name: Computer Systems Design I
CPEG 324.descr: Principles of computer system design are studied emphasizing tradeoffs involving cost, performance, testability, reliability and manufacturability. Topics include timing analysis, component and subsystem interconnect, noise effects debugging techniques, boundary scan testing and printed circuit layout. Laboratory work involves design and implementation of a computer subsystem.

CPEG 398.name: ECE Design & Entrepreneurship
CPEG 398.descr: Students work in small teams on various design challenges. The teams explore entrepreneurship opportunities by forming fictitious companies and selling their ideas.

CPEG 419.name: Computer Networks I
CPEG 419.descr: Foundation principles, architectures and techniques employed in computer and communication networks. Focuses on mechanisms used in TCP/IP protocol suite. Topics include connection management, end-to-end reliable data transfer, sliding window protocols, quality of service, flow control, congestion control, routing, LANs, framing, error control, analog versus digital transmission, packet versus circuit switching, multiplexing.
CPEG 419.restrict: Knowledge of probability and statistics recommended. Students who received credit in CISC250, CPEG419, CISC650, or ELEG651 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CPEG 421.name: Compiler Design
CPEG 421.descr: Introduction to compiler design, systax and semantics, code generation and optimization. Design of high performance computers together with high performance optimizing compilers as an integral unit. Software/hardware tradeoffs in pipelined computers, superscaler computers and computers embedded in other systems.

CPEG 422.name: Embedded Systems Hardware/Software Co-Design
CPEG 422.descr: Course covers hardware/software co-design approaches for building embedded systems. Topics include, but are not limited to:  microprocessors and FPGAs; VHD,; C, and Phython; gate-level, register transfer leve, and IP level design; hardware/software co-design; memory, bus, and IO ports; IP cores and customization; hardware accelerators, and cyber security.
CPEG 422.restrict: Students should have previous knowledge of VHDL programming language.

CPEG 423.name: PCB & FPGA Hardware Prototyping
CPEG 423.descr: This course focuses on the design, fabrication, and construction of Printed Circuit Boards and on using FPGA design kits.

CPEG 424.name: Analog Integrated Circuit Design
CPEG 424.descr: Course content will include: Advanced current mirrors, voltage references, amplifiers, frequency compensation, negative feedback systems and stability, Opamps, IC layout.

CPEG 455.name: High-Performance Computing with Commodity Hardware
CPEG 455.descr: New commodity computing devices, e.g., GPUs, bring the originally elite highperformance computing into the reach of general public. Principles of program optimization, GPU and IBM Cell architecture, along with concepts and techniques for optimizing general purpose computing on the new hardware.

CPEG 457.name: Search and Data Mining
CPEG 457.descr: With the increasing amount of textual information, it is important to develop effective search engines, such as Google, to help users manage and exploit the information. Examine the underlying technologies of search engines and get hands-on project experience. Requires good programming skills.

CPEG 460.name: Introduction to VLSI Systems
CPEG 460.descr: Study of CMOS VLSI devices, circuits and systems implemented in VLSI. CAD tools for the design and simulation of VLSI. Topics include the performance and limitations of VLSI systems, low level circuit design and system design with an emphasis on digital systems. Major chip design project required.
CPEG 460.restrict: Students should have previous knowledge of logic design and MOS transistor operation.

CPEG 465.name: Introduction to Cybersecurity
CPEG 465.descr: This cybersecurity course is an introduction to computer and network security and covers the foundation security policies and methods to provide confidentiality, integrity, and availability, as well as cryptography, auditing, and user security. Topics are reinforced with hands-on exercises run in a virtual machine environment.
CPEG 465.restrict: Students who have received credit in CISC 465, CISC665, CPEG665, ELEG 465, ELEG665, MISY 465 or MISY665 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CPEG 470.name: Web Applications Security
CPEG 470.descr: This seminar-style cybersecurity course covers one specific discipline of information security known as application security. This discipline (APPSEC) refers to the development of software that can continue to function correctly even under constant scrutiny and attack by determined adversaries.
CPEG 470.restrict: Programming experience in a high level language (e.g. C, C++, java, python).

CPEG 471.name: Pen Test and Reverse Engineering
CPEG 471.descr: This cybersecurity course introduces techniques used to (1) identify strengths and exploit weaknesses in networked systems or hosts, and (2) reverse engineer programs of unknown origin and identify their function so to classify them as malware and highlight the level of risk that they represent.
CPEG 471.preReq: CPEG 465/CPEG665 or CPEG 494/CPEG694. Programming experience in assembly language (CISC 260, CPEG 222, or equivalent).

CPEG 472.name: Applied Cryptography
CPEG 472.descr: This cybersecurity course explores modern Cryptography covering algorithms and cryptosystems, cryptanalysis, and best practices for application and implementation of crypto in software systems.
CPEG 472.restrict: Programming experience in a high level language (e.g. C, C++, java, python).

CPEG 473.name: Cloud Computing and Security
CPEG 473.descr: This cybersecurity course introduces the virtualization and cloud computing technologies used in most modern online services. The unique and conventional security issues related to protecting these types of systems are addressed and reinforced with hands-on exercises run in a virtual machine environment.
CPEG 473.preReq: CPEG 465/CPEG 665, ELEG 465/ELEG 665, CISC 465/CISC665, MISY 465/MISY 665 or CPEG 494/CPEG 694, ELEG 494/ELEG 694 or experience with virtualization and computer networking.

CPEG 475.name: IoT and Embedded Systems Security
CPEG 475.descr: The main emphasis of this course is cybersecurity for embedded systems devices and Internet of Things. The major topics covered include the instruction set and CPUs of embedded devices, the design of secure computing architectures from assembly program design to operating systems. Additional emphasis is given to Internet of Things applications, such as smart homes, embedded microprocessors and automotive systems.

CPEG 476.name: Secure Software Design
CPEG 476.descr: This cybersecurity course introduce the theory and practices used to help make a computer program secure and provide the skills needed to implement programs that are free from vulnerabilities.
CPEG 476.restrict: Programming experience in a high level language (e.g. C, C++, java, python). Graduate or upper level software course (design, etc.) recommended.

CPEG 494.name: System Hardening and Protection
CPEG 494.descr: Practical treatment of the defensive techniques used to harden computer systems to make them less vulnerable to cyber-attacks. Defect management, configuration/hardening, account control, logs/auditing, and risk assessment are covered and reinforced with hands-on exercises run in a virtual machine environment.

CPEG 495.name: Digital Forensics
CPEG 495.descr: Introduction to digital forensics as used to analyze criminal evidence in computer systems and digital media. Forensic tools and techniques for storage and memory analysis of windows/linux, network traffic, documentation are covered and reinforced with hands-on exercises run in a virtual machine environment.

CPEG 496.name: Topics in Cybersecurity
CPEG 496.descr: Explore varied topics in cybersecurity to coincide with the interests of students and current faculty. Potential topics include: (1) applications, web or cloud security, (2) risk management and incident response, (3) malware and reverse engineering, or (4) wireless, smartphone, or SCADA security.

CPEG 497.name: Advanced Cybersecurity
CPEG 497.descr: This seminar course explores areas in advanced computer and network security not covered in introductory cybersecurity classes. Provides insight into realistic complex defensive and offensive cybersecurity topics such as DoS attacks, DNS security, Email spam, On-line Authentication, Phishing, Cloud Security, Malware, and Web security.
CPEG 497.preReq: CPEG 465/CPEG665. Familiarity with basic networking protocols and operating systems.

CPEG 498.name: Senior Design I
CPEG 498.descr: Students apply their accumulated classroom knowledge to an electrical and computer engineering design problem.  Students work in small teams and must present their finished designs at the end of the term.

CPEG 499.name: Senior Design II
CPEG 499.descr: Students apply their accumulated classroom knowledge to an electrical and computer engineering design problem. Students work in small teams and must present their finished designs at the end of the term.

CRJU 110.name: Introduction to Criminal Justice
CRJU 110.descr: Responses in American society to the problems of crime. Examines criminal behavior, criminal law, the police, the courts and corrections, as well as selected issues in criminal justice.
CRJU 110.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

CRJU 120.name: Illicit Drug Use in America
CRJU 120.descr: The nature and extent of illicit drug use in the United States and the sociocultural context. The history and effects of the major drugs of abuse and the social issues since the 1950s that contributed to the increased use of illicit drugs.

CRJU 201.name: Problems of Law Enforcement
CRJU 201.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

CRJU 202.name: Problems of Criminal Judiciary
CRJU 202.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

CRJU 203.name: Problems of Corrections
CRJU 203.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

CRJU 301.name: Introduction to Legal Studies
CRJU 301.descr: Introduces legal studies as a multidisciplinary field.

CRJU 302.name: Social Deviance
CRJU 302.descr: Defining deviance, research on deviance and explaining deviance.
CRJU 302.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

CRJU 303.name: Juvenile Delinquency
CRJU 303.descr: Historical definition of delinquency, abuse and neglect, research in delinquency, causes and treatment of delinquents.
CRJU 303.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

CRJU 304.name: Criminology
CRJU 304.descr: The nature, kinds and causes of crime. Criminal liability, criminal careers and organized racketeering.
CRJU 304.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

CRJU 312.name: History of Crime and Criminal Justice
CRJU 312.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

CRJU 322.name: Crowds, Cults and Revolutions
CRJU 322.descr: Analysis of forms of behavior in relatively unstructured situations such as crowds, panics, riots and demonstrations; and processes of interaction: susceptibility, contagion, polarization and communication.
CRJU 322.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

CRJU 324.name: American Constitutional History
CRJU 324.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

CRJU 325.name: Issues in Emergency Management
CRJU 325.descr: Overview of the development of emergency management in the United States, including the formation of the profession, integration of formal and informal organizations, crisis response, and perceptions of crime and deviance during emergencies.

CRJU 335.name: Crime and Justice in Film and Literature
CRJU 335.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

CRJU 336.name: The Detective in Film and Fiction
CRJU 336.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

CRJU 344.name: Law Policy and Society
CRJU 344.descr: The aim of this course is to give you an introduction to global legal systems, how they operate and what they mean for overall governance. The course questions how legal systems function as parts of their respective societies and how these systems address certain areas of law, such as human rights, criminal and environmental law. During the course, we will also learn about the political, historical and cultural underpinnings that influence what we call “law”.

CRJU 345.name: Sociology of Law
CRJU 345.descr: Analysis of law as a social process in both historical and comparative perspective. Focuses on various theories of law and society and relevant empirical research.
CRJU 345.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

CRJU 351.name: Comparative Criminal Justice Systems
CRJU 351.descr: Study of different criminal justice systems across the world including discussions of their approaches to law, policing, courts, and corrections, common law, civil law, Islamic traditions as well as others.
CRJU 351.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

CRJU 352.name: International Criminal Justice
CRJU 352.descr: Introduction to basic structures of international criminal justice systems including international and transnational crime, international courts, transnational policing, and international criminal law.
CRJU 352.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

CRJU 368.name: Independent Research
CRJU 368.descr: Independent research under the supervision of a faculty member. Requirements include preparation of a research report consistent with the professional literature in the field. Student and faculty member will file a learning contract describing the research and a report with the department chair.

CRJU 401.name: Senior Seminar
CRJU 401.descr: Culminates the legal studies minor by requiring an independent research project resulting in a term paper. Seminar focuses on a specific substantive issue, provides guidance from professor and chance to share ideas and problems with fellow students.

CRJU 408.name: Advocacy, Community, and Practice in Domestic Violence Services
CRJU 408.descr: Reflects the current state of policy and practice among policy makers and practitioners in the field of domestic violence including legal issues, policy development, primary prevention, and models of best practice. Addresses the role of federal and state law. May include economic justice, mental health and trauma, and alternative models.

CRJU 409.name: Domestic Violence Services
CRJU 409.descr: Examines issues in providing services to families in which domestic violence is occurring. Multiple service systems are explored, with emphasis on service coordination, service gaps, and public policy.
CRJU 409.restrict: Open to juniors and seniors only.
CRJU 409.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

CRJU 417.name: Sex Crimes and Punishments
CRJU 417.descr: Discuss controversial topics surrounding sex crimes and punishments to develop students’ abilities to think critically about connections between three areas: how we as a society respond to crime through our criminal justice systems; what we believe about crime and punishment; and what empirical research tells us.

CRJU 424.name: Women in Literature and Society
CRJU 424.descr: This INSIDE/OUT class focuses on deep reading of several form of literature. The class investigates the role of women in literature as authors, readers and central characters, and uses literature as a window into social views of gender.   Assigned material explores the particular themes of voice, agency, cultural difference and social structure.

CRJU 428.name: Corporate Crime
CRJU 428.descr: Nature and causes of the deviant behaviors and crimes of large organizations. How organizations act, are accused of deviance and defend themselves in cases such as price-fixing, sale of unsafe drugs and illegal spying.

CRJU 431.name: Research on Violence
CRJU 431.descr: Violence is a very common part of modern life.  It pervades many aspects of our social interactions, and dominates political discourse and policy issues. The purpose of this course is to critically examine the nature and patterns of violence. A key element of the course that distinguishes it from other courses is that there is a statistical lab component that will be devoted to examining the epidemiology and etiology of violence using read data sets.  Therefore, this class is not just lecture based, but places equal emphasis on statistical techniques to answer empirical questions about violent offending and victimization.

CRJU 432.name: HIV/AIDS and Crime in South Africa
CRJU 432.descr: Examines two major social problems in South Africa: crime and HIV/AIDS.  Explore the problems historically, as well as their current prevalence and implications for the country. Examines sociological theories to broaden our understanding of the social problems which are compared with the US.

CRJU 435.name: Punishing Speech
CRJU 435.descr: Examines the use of the criminal law and other regulatory sanctions to punish certain types of speech and the efforts of courts to determine which speech is deserving of constitutional protection and therefore beyond governmental control.

CRJU 451.name: Topics in Crime, Law and Society: Inside/Out
CRJU 451.descr: Examination of current issues, scholarship, and debates related to crime, law, and social policy. Topics will vary. Taught in the Inside-Out format, in which traditional UD students and incarcerated persons take the class together at a local correctional facility.
CRJU 451.restrict: Permission of instructor. May be taken twice for credit when topics vary.

CRJU 452.name: Drugs and the Criminal Justice System
CRJU 452.descr: Covers both drug and criminal justice issues, focusing on the drugs-crime nexus and the criminal justice system response. Examines issues of race, gender, victimization, international policy, and new policy responses including drug treatment, harm reduction, and restorative justice. Class is held at a local correctional facility, and half the students are inmates.

CRJU 456.name: Surveillance and Society
CRJU 456.descr: Explores taken for granted systems of surveillance sociologically. Going beyond media constructed understandings, the class is designed to explore multiple forms of surveillant practices and technologies from at both personal and public levels of engagement.

CRJU 495.name: Field Experience in Criminal Justice
CRJU 495.restrict: Requires permission of instructor. Not for major credit.

DANC 101.name: Introduction to the Art of Dance
DANC 101.descr: Provide the basis for understanding, appreciating, and participating in dance as an art form, cultivated through lectures, films, live performances, and/or studio experiences.
DANC 101.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

DANC 201.name: Careers in Dance
DANC 201.descr: Dance Minor students and others interested in a career in dance will gain knowledge of the wide range of options in the dance field. Careers including performer, choreographer, educator, writer, critic, studio owner, and scientist will be explored in this survey course.

DANC 202.name: Beginning Ballet
DANC 202.descr: Designed for students who have not previously studied ballet. Students develop technical facility in basic ballet steps, knowledge of ballet class structure, an understanding of ballet class etiquette, and an understanding of the body as an instrument of expression.
DANC 202.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

DANC 203.name: Beginning Modern Dance
DANC 203.descr: Designed for students without prior dance experience. Introduction to the fundamentals of modern dance technique and vocabulary through a varied range of movement experiences. Contraction/release and fall/recovery discussed so as to increase the strength and mobility of the spine, and to find the full use of the breath in movement.
DANC 203.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

DANC 204.name: Beginning Jazz Dance
DANC 204.descr: Designed for students without prior dance experience. Introductory experience in movement vocabularies of the American dance form of jazz, demonstrating its evolution as both an art form and vehicle for individual and group expression. Emphasis on rhythm and style.
DANC 204.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

DANC 206.name: Dance in Culture and Society
DANC 206.descr: Explores the world of dance.  Through video observation, readings, writings, and dancing, students are exposed to many facets of dance as an expression of cultural values. Dance as art, religion, social custom, and political action  examined as evidenced in many human societies.
DANC 206.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

DANC 207.name: Dance Improvisation
DANC 207.descr: Dance improvisation provides the student opportunities to explore the processes of discovering, creating, and performing movement spontaneously with an emphasis on freedom of self expression and creative awareness. Through these processes, students develop an understanding of the artistic foundations necessary for performance, choreography, and teaching.
DANC 207.preReq: One course from the following: DANC 202, DANC 203, DANC 204, DANC 302, DANC 303, DANC 304, or permission if instructor.
DANC 207.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

DANC 208.name: Dance Composition I
DANC 208.descr: Introduction to elements of dance (time, space, energy) and to principles of composing movement for the solo performer. Develops a foundation of knowledge, skills, and processes for choreography appropriate to dance performance in any dance genre.
DANC 208.preReq: One course from the following: DANC 202, DANC 203, DANC 204, DANC 302, DANC 303, DANC 304, or permission of instructor.
DANC 208.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

DANC 209.name: Dance in Film
DANC 209.descr: View and discuss dance and movement in silent film, MGM movie musicals, dance featured cinema, reality TV shows and dance choreographed specifically for the camera.
DANC 209.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

DANC 210.name: Performance Practicum in Dance
DANC 210.descr: Designated for participation in the annual dance minor concert. All students must attend auditions held early in the semester. For those cast in a piece, class time will be rehearsal time. For those not cast, time will be spent as an assigned understudy or stage and tech crew.
DANC 210.preReq: One dance technique course, or permission of instructor.
DANC 210.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

DANC 302.name: Intermediate Ballet
DANC 302.descr: Designed for students who have a prior knowledge of basic ballet steps. Development of their technical skills in the ballet movement vocabulary through increasing speed, complexity, and duration of exercises. Development of stability and agility as a dancer emphasized.
DANC 302.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

DANC 303.name: Intermediate Modern Dance
DANC 303.descr: Designed for students with prior dance experience. A continuation of DANC 203 with added emphasis on increased technical accuracy, extension of range and control, and clarity of performance for more complex dance sequences.
DANC 303.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

DANC 304.name: Intermediate Jazz Dance
DANC 304.descr: Designed for students with prior dance experience. A continuation of DANC 204 with added emphasis on increased technical accuracy, extension of range and control, and clarity of performance for more complex dance sequences.
DANC 304.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

DANC 305.name: Hip Hop
DANC 305.descr: Studies the development, history, communication style, dance form, and processes of creation through the urban expressive cultural phenomenon of hip-hop dance.
DANC 305.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

DANC 306.name: Musical Theatre Styles
DANC 306.descr: Designed for students with prior dance experience. An experiential historical overview of musical theatre dance styles from 20th century America to the present. Explores the roots and reinventions of vernacular dance in America as it revealed itself on the musical theatre stage.
DANC 306.preReq: One course from the following: DANC 202, DANC 203, DANC 204, DANC 302, DANC 303, DANC 304, or permission of instructor.
DANC 306.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

DANC 307.name: Ethnic Dance Styles
DANC 307.descr: Variable topics course from an array of cultural dance forms. Topics include dance forms of Africa, India, Hawaii, Brazil, among others.
DANC 307.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

DANC 309.name: Repertory
DANC 309.descr: Rehearsal and performance of repertoire from established choreographers. Development of dance performance skills through restaging, rehearsal, and informal and formal presentation of choreography.
DANC 309.preReq: One course from the following: DANC 202, DANC 203, DANC 204, DANC 302, DANC 303, DANC 304, or permission of instructor.
DANC 309.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

DANC 310.name: Methods of Teaching Dance
DANC 310.descr: Introduction to teaching dance in educational setting with emphasis on designing and delivering developmentally appropriate units of instruction and pedagogical analysis of effective teaching behaviors. Includes classroom management, teaching strategies, and performance-based assessment of pupil achievement.
DANC 310.preReq: One course from the following: DANC 202, DANC 203, DANC 204, DANC 302, DANC 303, DANC 304, or permission of instructor.
DANC 310.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

DANC 312.name: The Body and Motion in Dance
DANC 312.descr: Study of the body and movement as relevant to dance. Emphasis on anatomical and kinesiological principles, alignment, somatics, prevention and care of injuries, motor learning, and motor development with applications relevant to performance, choreography, and pedagogy.
DANC 312.preReq: One course from the following: DANC 202, DANC 203, DANC 204, DANC 302, DANC 303, DANC 304, or permission of instructor.
DANC 312.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

DANC 313.name: Tap Dance
DANC 313.descr: Explore the fundamental technique, various styles, percussive rhythms and performance of tap dance. Through an in depth investigation of the basics, progressions, historical overview and development of the American dance form of tap, this course will demonstrate its evolution both as an art form and vehicle for individual and group expression. Previous dance experience is recommended but not required.
DANC 313.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

DANC 400.name: Dance in School and Community Settings
DANC 400.descr: Practical experience in an approved dance or dance-related setting. Each credit earned requires a minimum of 30 clock hours.
DANC 400.preReq: DANC 310 and Junior or Senior standing, or permission of instructor.

DANC 401.name: Dance Capstone Experience
DANC 401.descr: Interdisciplinary project that combines interest of student’s major with the dance minor. Projects may include research, outreach, technology, or original choreographic works.
DANC 401.preReq: Junior or Senior standing, or permission of instructor.

ECON 100.name: Economic Issues and Policies
ECON 100.descr: Takes a nontechnical approach to basic economics. Applies economic conceptsto contemporary issues, problems and policies. Covers both macro and microtopics.
ECON 100.restrict: Students who received credit in ECON101 or ECON103 are not eligible to take this course without permission.
ECON 100.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

ECON 101.name: Introduction to Microeconomics
ECON 101.descr: Introduces supply and demand concepts with basic economic graphs. Examines models of perfect and imperfect competition and determinants of production price and quantity. Covers microeconomic issues such as the effect of government regulation and environmental problems.
ECON 101.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

ECON 102.name: Civics and Economics for Teachers
ECON 102.descr: Provides teacher candidates with an understanding of the fundamental content and concepts embedded within the core social studies subjects of civics and economics as they relate to K-8 standards-based instruction. Focuses on developing an understanding of the content in the two subject areas and how that content might be taught effectively.
ECON 102.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S:

ECON 103.name: Introduction to Macroeconomics
ECON 103.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

ECON 251.name: Managerial Economics
