Classes will take place in a variety of campus locations based on assembly equipment and technology needed for demonstrations.

FASH 426.name: Fashion and Textile Collection Management
FASH 426.descr: Practicum at the University of Delaware Fashion and Textile Collection. Cover all aspects of proper care, storage and exhibition techniques for flat textiles, apparel and accessories. Experiences may include museum education, object accession, and database management.

FASH 430.name: Apparel Brand Management & Marketing
FASH 430.descr: A study of the significance of brand management for fashion companies as a competitive strategy for building sales and customer base. Introduction to the essential elements of branding, the course covers major activities of brand management and marketing with a focus on apparel firms. Apparel branding examined in global context due to the global nature of industry and its impact on fashion consumers around the world.

FASH 433.name: Advanced Apparel Product Development and Management
FASH 433.descr: The product development process as applied in the apparel industry. Focuses on all phases of apparel product development for a targeted market from conceptualization through execution of sample garments for mass production. Other topics include business planning, marketing, market research, distribution, and the product development calendar. Evaluates how product development activities support sustainability. Further develops skills in apparel industry technologies. Industry collaboration and field work are required.

FASH 455.name: Global Apparel and Textile Trade and Sourcing
FASH 455.descr: Global interdependencies that influence production, distribution, and consumer consumption. Study of the roles of government, industry, and consumers in the global economy with a focus on the apparel industry. Analyzes practices to improve sustainability in production of apparel.
FASH 455.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

FASH 484.name: Design Expressions
FASH 484.descr: Integrates advanced apparel design techniques and experiences as students design a collection of ensembles based on a theme incorporating social, cultural, and environmental sustainability. Articulating the design process through oral, written, and visual methods is emphasized.

FASH 490.name: Strategic Fashion Management
FASH 490.descr: A capstone course that integrates product planning and development, distribution, marketing, sourcing, and sustainability. Students will work on case studies and industry projects that require analysis, synthesis, and application of knowledge and skills within the global apparel industry.

FINC 120.name: Investment Club
FINC 120.descr: Prepares students interested in joining Blue Hen Investment Club(BHIC). Objective is to educate future members of BHIC to make better informed investment decisions. Students get hands-on experience learning.

FINC 200.name: Fundamentals of Finance
FINC 200.descr: Provides non-business majors with an overview of the role of finance within a business organization. Topics include financial statement analysis, time value of money, capital budgeting, valuation and the cost of capital.
FINC 200.restrict: No majors within business administration, finance or accounting, HRIM or MIS degree candidates may receive credit for this course.

FINC 311.name: Principles of Finance
FINC 311.descr: Introduces fundamental techniques and concepts related to the financial management of business firms. Topics include the time value of money, valuation, capital budgeting, working capital management, cost of capital, capital structure analysis, short and long term financing.
FINC 311.restrict: Not open to Freshmen. Open to students whose major requires this course.

FINC 312.name: Intermediate Financial Management
FINC 312.descr: Focuses on the role of the corporate financial manager in shareholder wealth maximization. Enhances the understanding of material covered in FINC 311 through the application of analytical methods, cases and the effective use of information technology in a contemporary financial environment.
FINC 312.restrict: Grade of C- or better required in STAT 200 and FINC 311.

FINC 314.name: Investments
FINC 314.descr: Examines the valuation of securities, the functioning of securities markets and the theory and practice of modern portfolio management. Topics include advanced techniques in security valuation, standards and practices in investment management, portfolio evaluation standards and applications using real-time data.
FINC 314.preReq: STAT 200 and MISY 262 or ECON 306 and FINC 311.
FINC 314.restrict: Grade of C- or better required in STAT 200 and MISY 262 or ECON 306 and FINC 311.

FINC 317.name: Real Estate Finance
FINC 317.descr: Introduces real estate theory and management. Topics include financing, evaluation and property management, housing policy, and governmental regulation and participation.
FINC 317.restrict: Grade of C- or better required in FINC 311.

FINC 320.name: Principles of Financial Planning
FINC 320.descr: Introduces the financial planning process and provides an overview of the specific areas of risk management and insurance, retirement, and investments. Topics include personal financial statements, cash flow and debt management, asset acquisition, education planning, the regulatory environment, the business of financial planning and ethics.
FINC 320.restrict: Grade of C- or better required in FINC 311. Required course for Financial Planning Major and may be a professional elective for Finance Major.

FINC 321.name: Insurance Planning
FINC 321.descr: Examines insurance and risk management decisions in personal financial planning. Topics include life, medical, disability, property, casualty, homeowners, liability, and auto insurance. Other topics include tax issues, annuities, group life insurance, long term care, and business insurance.
FINC 321.restrict: Grade of C- or better required in FINC 311. Required course for Financial Planning Major and may be a professional elective for Finance major.

FINC 322.name: Retirement Planning
FINC 322.descr: Focuses on public (Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid) and private (defined benefit and defined contribution plans) retirement plans and discusses issues that individuals face in retirement such as life-style choices and medical issues.
FINC 322.restrict: Grade of C- or better required in FINC 311. Required course for Financial Planning Major and may be a professional elective for Finance major.

FINC 354.name: Special Topics in Finance
FINC 354.restrict: For finance and financial planning majors only.

FINC 364.name: Finance in Practice
FINC 364.descr: Requires completion of at least 120 hours of finance-related internship with verification by the hiring company. Term paper relating the real-world duties and experiences of the internship to principles learned in the classroom also required.
FINC 364.restrict: Registration by permission of the department only.

FINC 392.name: Seminar on International Financial Management
FINC 392.descr: Seminar at an overseas location on selected topics in international financial management.  Combines lectures and visits to local organizations.  Research paper.
FINC 392.restrict: Used only as a professional elective for finance majors. Taught abroad.  The instructor will determine if the student has had relevant coursework in lieu of FINC 311.

FINC 412.name: Capital Markets & Financial Institutions
FINC 412.descr: Examines various types of financial institutions. Topics include structure, performance, asset/liability management, regulation and current issues that impact operational structures.
FINC 412.restrict: Open to Junior and Senior Finance Majors only & MISY majors with Finance concentration.

FINC 413.name: Capstone: Advanced Corporate Finance
FINC 413.descr: This capstone seminar course studies three different intersections of topics in global corporate finance: the intersections of a) currency and interest rate risk management, b) capital raising and securities market trading, and c) strategy and international financial management. The course emphasizes reports, exercises, cases, discussions, presentations, and analysis of financial news.
FINC 413.restrict: Open to Junior and Senior Finance Majors & MISY Majors with Finance concentrations only.

FINC 414.name: Bank Management
FINC 414.descr: Examines the management of commercial banks and similar institutions. Topics include funds and capital management, liquidity and credit standards, and lending and trust operations.
FINC 414.restrict: Open to Junior and Senior Finance majors & MISY Majors with Finance concentrations only.

FINC 415.name: International Finance
FINC 415.descr: Examines the international monetary environment and its impact on financial planning for the firm. Topics include exchange rates, currency restrictions, tax regulations, direct investment theory, capital budgeting, financing, risk management, and working capital management.
FINC 415.restrict: Open to Junior and Senior Finance Majors and International Business Studies major only

FINC 416.name: Derivative Securities and Risk Management
FINC 416.descr: Introduces the pricing, trading and use of derivative securities (forwards, futures, swaps and options contracts), emphasizing the management of risk arising from the volatility of exchange rates, interest rates and commodity and equity prices.

FINC 418.name: Seminar in Corporate Governance
FINC 418.descr: Examines current issues in corporate governance. Topics include executive compensation, shareholder resolutions and board of director ownership and accountability.

FINC 419.name: Financial Modeling and Valuation
FINC 419.descr: Financial modeling techniques to value IPOs, mergers, private equity transactions, and leveraged buyouts. Explore the economic principles supporting these techniques and apply them to various transaction types using real financial data. Focus is on bridging the gap between theory and practice.

FINC 420.name: Meet The Market
FINC 420.descr: Prepares students intending to pursue careers in finance markets about the latest innovations in the practice of finance. Course primarily consist of seminars delivered by leading finance professionals.
FINC 420.restrict: Open to FINC, ECON, and ACCT seniors, MSF students, MBA students, ECON Master and PhD students, and any student interested in pursuing a career in Finance only.

FINC 425.name: Financial Plan Development
FINC 425.descr: The capstone experience engages students in critical thinking and decision making about personal financial management topics, integrating the knowledge gained in previous courses into a cohesive, inclusive understanding of the financial planning process. A key component of this module will be to develop a comprehensive financial plan.
FINC 425.preReq: FINC 320, FINC 321, FINC 322, ACCT 313 or ACCT 413, and FINC 314.

FINC 426.name: Trust Management Symposium
FINC 426.descr: Go through the process of managing a trust, addressing corpus and income management, the needs of income and residual beneficiaries, and the legal obligations imposed on a fiduciary for multi-participant trusts and traditional trusts. Utilize a combination of case studies, presentations, and project work to achieve the learning objectives.
FINC 426.restrict: Open only to students in the Trust Management Minor program

FINC 459.name: Startup Finance & Raising Capital for Entrepreneurs
FINC 459.descr: Examines the sources of capital for new and growing companies with a special emphasis on angel investment, venture capital, private equity, and non-dilutive and other niche options; the management of cash flows; uses of capital; and financial statement presentation and analysis (a cornerstone of valuation, lending/borrowing, and investing). Case examples and live projects are emphasized to provide students with firsthand experience in financial decision making for startup and emerging growth businesses.

FINC 462.name: Fixed Income Securities
FINC 462.descr: An overview of the fixed income markets and instruments within those markets. Focus is on valuation and analysis of fixed income instruments and the roles of different participants within the fixed income markets.
FINC 462.restrict: Requires a grade of C- or better in FINC 311.

FREN 105.name: French I - Elementary
FREN 105.descr: Introduction to the French language and development of speaking, listening, reading and writing skills through the use of basic texts.

FREN 106.name: French II - Elementary/Intermediate
FREN 106.descr: Completion of basic French. Increasing mastery of the basic skills of speaking, listening, reading and writing.
FREN 106.restrict: Two to three years of high school French acceptable in lieu of prerequisite.

FREN 107.name: French III - Intermediate
FREN 107.descr: Review of grammar, continued practice in speaking and writing, and reading texts of average difficulty.
FREN 107.restrict: Four years of high school French acceptable in lieu of prerequisite. Satisfies College of Arts and Sciences language requirement.

FREN 114.name: French for Fashion
FREN 114.descr: French for Fashion is a one-credit elementary course (pass/fail) designed for beginners. With its emphasis on Paris and fashion, it prepares students for the winter FASH study abroad program, but anyone may take the course.
FREN 114.restrict: Students who received credit in FREN 107 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

FREN 200.name: Grammar and Composition
FREN 200.descr: Intensive grammar review of all major verb tenses and grammatical concepts (such as object pronouns). Emphasis is on grammar improvement through reading and writing.

FREN 205.name: French Conversation
FREN 205.descr: Practical use of French by means of oral reports and discussions. Emphasis on improvement of basic conversational skills. Grammar review where appropriate, and/or some written work.
FREN 205.preReq: FREN 107 or FREN 200 with a minimum grade of C.
FREN 205.restrict: Not intended for native speakers of French.

FREN 206.name: Culture Through Conversation
FREN 206.descr: Discussion of topics drawn from contemporary French life. Designed for students who wish to broaden their knowledge of French culture while improving their oral and aural language skills.

FREN 207.name: French Caribbean past and present
FREN 207.descr: Introduction to contemporary French Caribbean, its history, its culture, its people, their way of life and the issues confronting them. Focuses on Martinique.
FREN 207.restrict: Taught in English during Winter Session abroad. Not for minor credit.
FREN 207.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

FREN 208.name: Contemporary France I
FREN 208.descr: An introduction to contemporary France, its culture, its people, their way of life and the issues confronting them.
FREN 208.restrict: Not for major credit. Taught abroad only, in both English and French. Does not satisfy the foreign language requirement.
FREN 208.breadth: University: ; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

FREN 209.name: French Conversation Through Film
FREN 209.descr: Development of oral proficiency in French through discussion and analysis of major French films. Some written work and grammar review where appropriate.
FREN 209.preReq: FREN 107 or FREN 200 with a minimum grade of C.
FREN 209.restrict: Not intended for native speakers of French.

FREN 211.name: French Reading and Composition
FREN 211.descr: Reading and discussion of French literature. Frequent compositions. Grammar review where appropriate.
FREN 211.preReq: FREN 200 with a minimum grade of C or FREN 107 with a minimum grade of A-.
FREN 211.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

FREN 250.name: Introduction to Business French
FREN 250.descr: Familiarizes students with characteristics of business French (terminology, syntactical patterns, etc.) and policies and practices of the French business community.
FREN 250.preReq: Any 200-level course taught in the French language.

FREN 301.name: Self and Society
FREN 301.descr: A thematic and historical approach to French narrative from the Renaissance to the present day, focusing on the conflict between individual behavior and societal norms. Fosters understanding of French culture, history, and institutions.
FREN 301.preReq: FREN 211 and any 200-level course taught in the French language.
FREN 301.breadth: University: ; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

FREN 302.name: Love, Passion, Faith and Death
FREN 302.descr: An approach to French literature from the Renaissance to the contemporary era focusing on the themes of love, passion, faith and death, with particular attention to the historical context of the works studied. Through the exploration of poems and theater by major authors including Ronsard, Corneille, Hugo, and Baudelaire, the course fosters understanding of French culture, history, and institutions.
FREN 302.preReq: FREN 211 and any 200-level course taught in the French language.
FREN 302.breadth: University: ; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

FREN 303.name: Texts and Contexts
FREN 303.preReq: FREN 211 and any 200-level course taught in the French language.
FREN 303.restrict: May be repeated for credit when topics vary.

FREN 305.name: French Conversation and Composition
FREN 305.descr: Discussion of cultural, social and political topics in French-speaking countries. Vocabulary building, grammar exercises and compositions.
FREN 305.preReq: FREN 211 and one other 200-level FREN course taught in French.
FREN 305.restrict: Not intended for native speakers of French.

FREN 306.name: Practical Oral/Written Expression
FREN 306.descr: Strengthens grammar and vocabulary skills in preparation for advanced courses. Class exercises include oral exposes, discussion of articles and videos, textual analysis, and compositions.
FREN 306.preReq: Any two 200-level French courses conducted in the French language.

FREN 307.name: Practical Oral Expression
FREN 307.descr: Strengthens grammar and vocabulary skills in preparation for advanced courses, as well as everyday oral communication situations. Class exercises include oral exposes, skits, and discussion of articles & videos.
FREN 307.preReq: Any two 200-level French courses conducted in the French language.

FREN 308.name: Contemporary France
FREN 308.descr: Discussion and study of issues related to contemporary cultural, political and social developments in France, including its people in today’s European community.
FREN 308.preReq: Any two 200-level French courses taught in the French language.
FREN 308.restrict: Taught abroad only and in French.
FREN 308.breadth: University: ; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

FREN 309.name: Practical Written Expression
FREN 309.descr: Strengthens grammar and vocabulary skills through regular writing practice. Class exercises include compositions, analysis of literary texts, and study of authentic documents.
FREN 309.preReq: FREN 211 and any other 200-level FREN course taught in French.

FREN 314.name: French Phonetics
FREN 314.descr: Studies the sounds of the French language (both individual phonemes and items of connected speech, such as liaison, linking, intonation, etc.). Helps improve pronunciation of the language.
FREN 314.preReq: Any two 200-level French courses conducted in the French language.
FREN 314.restrict: Not intended for native speakers of French.

FREN 325.name: French Civilization I
FREN 325.descr: A study of French cultural history from Gaul to the French Revolution.
FREN 325.preReq: Any two 200-level French courses conducted in the French language.
FREN 325.breadth: University: ; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

FREN 326.name: French Civilization II
FREN 326.descr: A study of French cultural history from the French Revolution to 1945.
FREN 326.preReq: Any two 200-level French courses conducted in the French language.
FREN 326.breadth: University: ; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

FREN 350.name: Advanced Business French
FREN 350.descr: Development of strategies to initiate and maintain oral and written communication in the world of business. Acquisition of commercial vocabulary, practice in speaking French in business situations, letter writing and article reading. Functional and cultural approach.
FREN 350.preReq: Any two 200-level French courses, one preferably being FREN 250.

FREN 355.name: Special Topics:
FREN 355.descr: Explores an area of special interest in French literature or culture studies.

FREN 376.name: Introduction to French Culture and Society

FREN 403.name: Structure of French
FREN 403.descr: Study of the sounds, morphology and syntax of the French language, as well as of discursive phenomena. Introduces students to the science of lingustics as applied to French.Taught in French.
FREN 403.preReq: Two 300-level French courses, one of which should be FREN 314.
FREN 403.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

FREN 404.name: Advanced Composition and Grammar
FREN 404.descr: Intensive writing practice in French (seven compositions, all to be revised), with systematic grammar review: past tenses, articles, adjectives, participles, passive voice, the conditional, the subjunctive, concordance of verb tenses, demonstrative pronouns.

FREN 405.name: Translation and Stylistics
FREN 405.descr: Focuses on vocabulary and translation skills (from French into English and vice-versa).
FREN 405.preReq: ONE of FREN 301, FREN 302, or FREN 303, plus one other 3XX.

FREN 406.name: Advanced French Language
FREN 406.descr: Grammatical structure and stylistics with special attention given to technical vocabulary and discourse.

FREN 407.name: Advanced Oral French
FREN 407.descr: Varied activities help students develop their oral expression and comprehension and gain confidence in oral communication situations. Class exercises include oral exposes, skits, discussion of articles and videos.

FREN 409.name: Advanced Written French
FREN 409.descr: Strengthens grammar and vocabulary skills through regular writing practice. Class exercises include compositions, analysis of literary texts, and study of authentic documents. Study of grammar and stylistics, with special attention given to technical vocabulary and discourse.

FREN 411.name: Great Authors I: 1100-1750
FREN 411.descr: Selected readings of master authors and works from the Middle Ages to the Age of Enlightenment. Authors may include Villon, Rabelais, Montaigne, Moliere, Corneille, Mme. de Lafayette, Montesquieu, Voltaire, and others.
FREN 411.preReq: Two 300-level French courses, including at least ONE of: FREN 301, FREN 302, or FREN 303.

FREN 412.name: Great Authors II: 1750-Present
FREN 412.descr: Selected readings of master authors and works from the dawn of Romanticism to the present. Authors may include Prevost, Rousseau, Hugo, Flaubert, Baudelaire, Gide, Proust, Camus, Sartre, Ionesco, Beckett, Duras, and others.
FREN 412.preReq: Two 300-level French courses, including at least ONE of: FREN 301, FREN 302, or FREN 303.

FREN 423.name: French Medieval Literature
FREN 423.preReq: Two 300-level French courses, including at least ONE of FREN 301, FREN 302, or FREN 303.

FREN 424.name: French Renaissance Literature
FREN 424.descr: Selected works by Rabelais, the poets of the Pleiade, Montaigne, and others.
FREN 424.preReq: Two 300-level French courses, including at least ONE of FREN 301, FREN 302, or FREN 303.

FREN 437.name: Seventeenth Century French Theatre
FREN 437.descr: Growth of French dramatic literature before 1715 and analysis of the principal plays of Corneille, Racine, and Moliere.
FREN 437.preReq: Two 300-level French courses, including at least ONE of FREN 301, FREN 302, or FREN 303.

FREN 438.name: Seventeenth Century French Poetry and Prose
FREN 438.descr: Representative novelists, poets, critics and moralists from Descartes and Pascal to La Fontaine, Boileau, Mme. de La Fayette, and others.
FREN 438.preReq: Two 300-level French courses, including at least ONE of FREN 301, FREN 302, or FREN 303.

FREN 441.name: The Eighteenth Century: The Age of Voltaire
FREN 441.descr: Novels, plays, essays and poetry of such authors as Montesquieu, Marivaux, Prevost, and Voltaire.
FREN 441.preReq: Two 300-level French courses, including at least ONE of FREN 301, FREN 302, or FREN 303.

FREN 442.name: The Eighteenth Century: The Age of Rousseau
FREN 442.descr: Novels, plays, essays and poetry of such authors as Diderot, Rousseau, Beaumarchais, and Chenier.
FREN 442.preReq: Two 300-level French courses, including at least ONE of FREN 301, FREN 302, or FREN 303.

FREN 445.name: Nineteenth Century French Novel
FREN 445.descr: The novel from Romanticism to Naturalism. Chateaubriand, Balzac, Stendhal, Flaubert, Zola and others.
FREN 445.preReq: Two 300-level French courses, including at least ONE of FREN 301, FREN 302, or FREN 303.

FREN 446.name: Nineteenth Century French Poetry and Theatre
FREN 446.descr: Poets and dramatists representative of Romanticism, Realism and the Symbolist movement.
FREN 446.preReq: Two 300-level French courses, including at least ONE of FREN 301, FREN 302, or FREN 303.

FREN 451.name: Twentieth Century French Literature: The Age of Anxiety and the Absurd
FREN 451.descr: Main trends from Gide, Celine and Malraux to Camus, Sartre and Beckett, including Surrealism, Existentialism, and the Theatre of the Absurd.
FREN 451.preReq: Two 300-level French courses, including at least ONE of FREN 301, FREN 302, or FREN 303.

FREN 452.name: Aspects of Contemporary French Literature
FREN 452.descr: A study of contemporary French literature, including novels, plays, essays and poetry of such authors as Robbe-Grillet, Sarraute, Perec, Tournier, Duras, Ponge, Bonnefoy, Jaccottet, and Barthes.
FREN 452.preReq: Two 300-level French courses, including at least ONE of FREN 301, FREN 302, or FREN 303.

FREN 453.name: Contemporary French Civilization: 1958-Present
FREN 453.descr: Culture, customs, and political & economic life in France since 1958.
FREN 453.preReq: Two 300-level French courses, including at least ONE of FREN 301, FREN 302, or FREN 303.

FREN 454.name: French Cinema
FREN 454.descr: Study of modern French cultural history through the films of such masters as Vigo, Gance, Pagnol, Renoir, Bresson, Resnais, Malle, and others.
FREN 454.preReq: Two 300-level French courses, including at least ONE of FREN 301, FREN 302, or FREN 303.

FREN 455.name: Selected Authors, Works and Themes
FREN 455.descr: Works of one or more outstanding authors or on a special theme.
FREN 455.preReq: Two 300-level French courses, including at least ONE of FREN 301, FREN 302, or FREN 303.
FREN 455.restrict: May be repeated for credit when topics vary.

FREN 456.name: French Theater Workshop
FREN 456.descr: Study of French theater of different periods and genres, with an emphasis on staging and performance. Class activities include dramatic readings, improvisation, and exercises to improve diction. Culminates in a public presentation of students’ work.
FREN 456.preReq: Two 300-level French courses, including at least ONE of FREN 301, FREN 302, or FREN 303.

FREN 457.name: The Francophone World
FREN 457.descr: Examines the social, cultural, political, and historical aspects of various regions of the Francophone world (the Maghreb, Sub-Saharan Africa, the Caribbean, South East Asia [Vietnam] and Lebanon) as well as the Beur (descendants of the first generation of Maghrebi immigrants) phenomenon in the French banlieue (suburbs). Texts and films serve as points of entry into these multicultural communities.
FREN 457.preReq: Two 300-level French courses, including at least ONE of FREN 301, FREN 302, or FREN 303.

FREN 458.name: Francophone African Cinema
FREN 458.descr: The cinemas of Francophone Africa from the 1960s to the present. Analysis of how African filmmakers have challenged and refocused prior and degrading images by creating new depictions of their societies, and offering Africa through African eyes. Exploration of the social, historical, and political contexts of these films as well as examination of each of them closely to better understand their aesthetic and narrative characteristics. Appreciation of local frameworks of knowledge and of recent theoretical developments in film studies.
FREN 458.preReq: Two 300-level French courses, including at least ONE of FREN 301, FREN 302, or FREN 303.

FREN 459.name: Negritude, Antillanite, Creolite
FREN 459.descr: Focuses on the literary movements of Negritude, Antillanité, and Creolité, and their relation to Caribbean identity, culture and history, as well as to the field of Francophone postcolonial studies.
FREN 459.preReq: Two 300-level French courses, including at least ONE of FREN 301, FREN 302, or FREN 303.

FREN 460.name: Littérature Francophone Issue de l’Immigration
FREN 460.descr: Introduction to literary productions by African, Caribbean, and Asian immigrants in France. Acquire a understanding of relevant strands of current theoretical thinking through close analysis of texts. Examine recurrent themes and forms in immigrant literature, including: representation of identity; concepts of origins; intersection of race, class and gender; and textual strategies underpinning these considerations. Examine different ways these authors are redefining French literature.

FREN 476.name: Topics in French Culture and Society

GAME 201.name: Introduction to Game Studies
GAME 201.descr: Examine the major genres of videogames produced around the world, and major critical approaches taken by academics to the study of those games. Issues for discussion may include the dominance of console platforms in some markets and PC gaming in others; ethics and violence in games; representations of gender and race; processes of immersion and identification in different game types; and the effect of increasingly realistic environments and cinematics.
GAME 201.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

GAME 351.name: Videogames and Japanese Culture
GAME 351.descr: Examines Japanese videogames from both a ludological and narratological perspective. Genres studies include the JRPG, stealth action, simulation and fighting games.
GAME 351.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

GAME 352.name: Videogames and Latin American Culture
GAME 352.descr: Explores the relationship between videogames and culture by analyzing both in-game cultural representation and the real-life economic, political and societal effects of games across Latin America.
GAME 352.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

GAME 401.name: Game Studies and eSports Internship
GAME 401.descr: The Game Studies and Esports Internship provides a hands-on educational experience. The internship is based on practical experience working directly in the games and esports industry, combined with traditional academic components. Student activities include the application of important theories/concepts gleaned from prior coursework, informing periodic reflection assignments. Towards the end of spring semester or summer session, students will deliver a formal oral presentation to their fellow Game Studies and esports students, faculty members, and professionals in the field. These presentations will be open to the university community and general public. Lastly, evaluation surveys will be completed by both the student intern and the on-site supervisor. These evaluations will help the course instructor measure the overall quality of the internship learning experience and the quality of the student’s performance.
GAME 401.restrict: GAME 401 is restricted to majors in Game Studies and eSports in their Junior or Senior years, or with advisor approval

GAME 490.name: Capstone Seminar in Game Studies and eSports
GAME 490.descr: This Capstone Seminar focuses on the multifaceted process of video game development, distribution and reception. Each week’s discussion will focus on one facet of a typical game development workflow (i.e., Writing, Programming, Sound), or a specific aspect of game reception (i.e., Game Analysis, eSports, Community Outreach). Likewise, the course highlights the fundamental role of diversity and inclusion for understanding game culture and the game industry, examining the intersections of gender, race, sexual identity and nationality on video game production and consumption. Ultimately, this Capstone Seminar will give GAME majors the interdisciplinary tools to understand the many steps involved in game development, as well as the many perspectives that inform the reception of video games by critics and audiences. It will also provide the structure to allow senior GAME majors to complete a final Capstone Project, as the culmination to their studies in the major.
GAME 490.restrict: For senior-level GAME majors and students with advisor approval only

GEOL 105.name: Geological Hazards and Their Human Impact
GEOL 105.descr: Geological processes and events that adversely affect humans and civilization. Methods for predicting and dealing with geological hazards. May be taken with a 1 credit lab, GEOL 115.
GEOL 105.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

GEOL 107.name: Geology of Dynamic Earth
GEOL 107.descr: Principles of physical geology and its application in interpreting earth processes. Laboratory covers identification of earth materials and the interpretation of topographic and geologic maps.
GEOL 107.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S: GRP D LAB: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Tech w Lab

GEOL 108.name: Volcanoes and Earthquakes
GEOL 108.descr: Violent geologic activity as illustrated by volcanoes and earthquakes. The nature, causes and origins of volcanic and earthquake activity, their interactions with humans and their potential control.
GEOL 108.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

GEOL 109.name: Planets, Asteroids and Impacts
GEOL 109.descr: Composition, structure, surface features, origin, and evolution of the planets, satellites, asteroids, and comets. Also explores the possible connection between meteorite impacts and mass extinctions. Did an asteroid kill off the dinosaurs?
GEOL 109.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

GEOL 110.name: Earth’s Evolving Systems
GEOL 110.descr: History of the earth and its biota.  Origins, evolution and mass extinctionsof major groups of organisms as demonstrated by the earth’s fossil record.  Laboratory covers identification of basic fossil groups and exercises in interpreting Earth history.
GEOL 110.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

GEOL 113.name: Earth Science
GEOL 113.descr: Earth materials, structure and the geologic phenomena that produce them. Physical and temporal aspects of earth history. Laboratory examination of rocks, minerals and fossils. Experiments in geological processes and interpretation of geologic maps.
GEOL 113.restrict: Open to education majors and other selected programs.
GEOL 113.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S: GRP D LAB: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Tech w Lab

GEOL 115.name: Geological Hazards Laboratory
GEOL 115.descr: Laboratory investigation of environmental geological processes and their impact on society: earthquakes, volcanoes, coastal hazards, rivers and streams, groundwater. Identification of earth materials and study of earth processes using topographical, geological and tectonic maps.
GEOL 115.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S: GRP D LAB: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Tech w Lab

GEOL 120.name: Life’s a Beach: Geological Processes & Living with the Coast
GEOL 120.descr: Introduction to geology of the coast. “Reading” beaches by geological phenomenon and physical processes. Historical and contemporary analysis of how populations have chosen to live with or against the natural dictates of the shore with costly and tragic consequences. One-day field trip required.
GEOL 120.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

GEOL 130.name: Geology of the National Parks
GEOL 130.descr: Introduction to field geology using the some of the best geological features of the world found in U.S. national parks. Travel for 3 to 4 weeks to nearly a dozen parks where hands-on experiences are used to evaluate how the Earth works.

GEOL 202.name: Introduction to Earth Materials
GEOL 202.descr: Physical, chemical, and optical properties of minerals and other earth materials; structure and composition of rock-forming minerals; Introduction to equilibrium concepts, and basic chemical thermodynamics as applied to earth materials.
GEOL 202.preReq: GEOL 107 or instructor consent. CHEM 103/CHEM 133 and MATH 241 are recommended but not required.

GEOL 203.name: Earth Surface Processes
GEOL 203.descr: Processes and history of near-surface geologic environments of the Earth (potential areas of focus may include rivers, hillslopes, coastal environments, deltas, glaciers, periglacial environments, etc.). Human impacts on surficial environments.

GEOL 215.name: Understanding Climate Change
GEOL 215.descr: Understanding climate and climate change is important for everyone.  Explores climate change and its impacts at local, regional, and global levels.  Policy and decision making, as well as adaptation and mitigation will be discussed with a focus on current events.
GEOL 215.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S:

GEOL 302.name: Igneous and Metamorphic Petrology
GEOL 302.descr: Origin, composition, structure, distribution, and uses of igneous and metamorphic rocks. Lectures focus on occurrences of rocks as a function of geologic setting. Labs focus on identification of rock types and interpretation of their formation conditions.

GEOL 304.name: Sedimentology and Stratigraphy
GEOL 304.descr: Study of sediment focusing on how it is transported and deposited including fluid flow and sediment transport, sedimentary structures and textures. Environments of deposition with modern/ancient analogs. Description and correlation of stratigraphic units including facies analysis, basin analysis and concepts of time and methods of absolute dating.

GEOL 305.name: Structural Geology and Plate Tectonics
GEOL 305.descr: The study of geologic structures, geologic stress and the responses of rocks to stress. Examines plate tectonics and the major structural and tectonic relations generated at plate boundaries.

GEOL 306.name: Geoscience Field Methods
GEOL 306.descr: This is a 30-day-long field course in the western USA focused on advanced training and experience in geological field methods. Key topics include rock descriptions, stratigraphic analysis and correlation, structural methods, and geologic map construction and interpretation.
GEOL 306.preReq: GEOL 105 and GEOL 115, or GEOL 107, or GEOL 113; GEOL 305

GEOL 307.name: The Earth’s History I: Paleobiology
GEOL 307.descr: Recognition, biology and paleobiology of major groups of invertebrates. Use of the fossil record in solving environmental and paleoenvironmental problems. Principles of stratigraphy and correlation and origin and development of the geologic time scale.
GEOL 307.preReq: GEOL 105 and GEOL 115, or GEOL 107, or GEOL 113

GEOL 341.name: Climate and Climate Change
GEOL 341.descr: Understanding the earth’s climate and how the climate is changing is a fundamental part of modern earth system science. Explores the scientific basis for the study of climate and climate change, including long term and modern change, with a discussion of current topics.

GEOL 401.name: Senior Seminar: Topics in Geoscience
GEOL 401.descr: Integrated examination of topics and concepts of current interest and importance in geoscience. Topics may vary.
GEOL 401.preReq: Senior geology majors only, within 30 credits of graduation.

GEOL 405.name: Introduction to Research
GEOL 405.descr: Undergraduate research carried out under the supervision of the staff. Writtenreport required.
GEOL 405.restrict: May be repeated once if project warrants it.

GEOL 411.name: Fluvial Geomorphology
GEOL 411.descr: Hydrologic and sediment transport processes in rivers and watersheds. Morphology and evolution of rivers and watersheds. Depositional processes and evolution of floodplains. Structure and interpretation of fluvial deposits in the geologic record.
GEOL 411.preReq: GEOL 107 or permission of the instructor.

GEOL 414.name: Quaternary Geology and Geochronology
GEOL 414.descr: Survey of the stratigraphy and chronology of marine and terrestrial records and theories of climatic change. Studies of the stratigraphy of significant Quaternary successions throughout the world and their correlation and absolute dating.
GEOL 414.preReq: GEOL 107 or permission of the instructor.

GEOL 419.name: Environmental Geochemistry
GEOL 419.descr: Origin and distribution of elements and isotopes in geological materials; principles of geochemical thermodynamics, aqueous geochemistry and mineral-water interactions pertaining to geochemical reactions and transport of the elements in the Earth’s near-surface environment; introduction to terrestrial, oceanic, and atmospheric geochemical cycles.

GEOL 421.name: Environmental and Applied Geology
GEOL 421.descr: The application of geologic principles to matters of environmental concern. Discussion, examples, techniques and case histories in water supply, waste disposal, zoning and land use, mining, legislation, regulation and professionalism emphasizing the role of geologist and the educated citizen.
GEOL 421.preReq: GEOL 107 or permission of the instructor.

GEOL 422.name: OSHA 40-Hour Hazardous Materials Safety Training
GEOL 422.descr: OSHA 40-hour safety training certification hazardous waste operations health and safety training program. Includes material from environmental regulations, hazard recognition, toxicology, environmental monitoring, personal protective equipment, site characterization and analysis, site zone and control, health and safety plans, decontamination and spill response recovery.
GEOL 422.restrict: GEOL422 cannot be applied toward the nine credits of 400-level geology electives required of BS geology majors.

GEOL 426.name: Alpine Environmental Field Methods
GEOL 426.descr: Introduction to field measurement techniques and field analysis during a travel and field learning experience to an alpine area. Field mapping, observation, use of handheld instrumentation, and field estimation methods.

GEOL 427.name: Introduction to Geological Remote Sensing
GEOL 427.descr: Principles of active and passive remote sensing data interpretation for geologists. Study of geomorphic, structural, and lithologic characteristics of the Earth as observed in aerial and satellite data. Emphasis on the use of multispectral, radar, and LiDAR data for geologic mapping.

GEOL 428.name: Hydrogeology
GEOL 428.descr: Principles of groundwater flow and water chemistry in varied geologic media.Evaluation of groundwater resources and assessment of environmental problemsassociated with groundwater use.
GEOL 428.preReq: MATH 241 (MATH 242 recommended) or permission of the instructor.
GEOL 428.restrict: Students who received credit in CIEG498 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

GEOL 434.name: Geology of Coasts
GEOL 434.descr: Erosional, depositional and tectonic processes; morphology and classification, and geologic history of the coastal areas of the world.

GEOL 445.name: Geomicrobiology
GEOL 445.descr: How microorganisms drive geological processes in modern environments, and the roles of microbial life on ancient Earth.  Discussion of literature on topics such as biomineralization, weathering, microfossils, biomarkers, astrobiology, genomics, evolution, and redox history of Earth.

GEOL 453.name: Introduction to Geophysics
GEOL 453.descr: Introduction to geophysical methods that may include seismic reflection and refraction, side-scan sonar, multibeam sonar, ground-penetration radar (GPR), LiDAR, and resistivity exploration methods and interpretations. Additional topics that could be addressed include seismology, magnetism, gravity, and geodesy.
GEOL 453.preReq: GEOL 107 or GEOL 105/GEOL 115 or GEOL 113; PHYS 201/PHYS 221; MATH 115, MATH 117, MATH 221, or MATH 241.

GEOL 458.name: Paleoclimatology
GEOL 458.descr: Covers the factors that cause natural variations in Earth’s climate on different time scales, focusing on biotic, geologic, and geochemical records. Includes discussion of changing continental configurations, atmospheric greenhouse gas levels, and the Earth-Sun geometry on ocean circulation and climate change.

GEOL 469.name: Geology of the US Southwest
GEOL 469.descr: Study of the geology of the US Southwest. Course includes a one week field trip to the Southwest during Spring Break. Locations to be determined. There will be a student fee for this course. Contact the department for additional information.

GEOL 489.name: Eco-Entrepreneurship Practicum
GEOL 489.restrict: Completion of a basic entrepreneurship course prior to enrollment is strongly recommended.

GRMN 103.name: Introductory German for Engineers
GRMN 103.descr: Students will engage with content from multiple disciplines-STEM, the arts, and the humanities-while building transferrable, real-world skills including collaboration, problem solving, time management, and global awareness. They will build linguistic and intercultural competence with respect to the German-speaking world.

GRMN 104.name: Introductory German for Engineers II
GRMN 104.descr: Introductory German for Engineers II-designed specifically for Engineering students-builds on the material learned in GRMN 103.  It takes an interdisciplinary, progressive approach to learning German, with meaningful, content-based tasks designed to promote communication and critical thinking.  Students will engage with content from multiple disciplines-STEM, the arts, and the humanities-while building transferrable, real-world skills including collaboration, problem solving, time management, global awareness and cultural competency.

GRMN 105.name: German I - Elementary
GRMN 105.descr: Introduction to the German language and development of speaking, listening, reading and writing skills through the use of basic texts.

GRMN 106.name: German II - Elementary/Intermediate
GRMN 106.descr: Completion of basic German. Increasing mastery of the basic skills of speaking, listening, reading and writing.
GRMN 106.restrict: Two to three years of high school German acceptable in lieu of prerequisite.

GRMN 107.name: German III - Intermediate
GRMN 107.descr: Review of grammar, continued practice in speaking and writing, and reading texts of average difficulty.
GRMN 107.restrict: Four years of high school German acceptable in lieu of prerequisite. Satisfies College of Arts and Sciences language requirement.

GRMN 200.name: German Grammar Review
GRMN 200.descr: Systematic review of elementary and intermediate German grammar. Emphasis on grammar. Conversational practice.
GRMN 200.restrict: Not intended for students who have already taken a 300 or 400-level course in German.

GRMN 205.name: German Conversation
GRMN 205.descr: Practical use of German by means of oral reports and discussions. Emphasis on improvement of basic conversational skills. Grammar review and written work where appropriate.
GRMN 205.restrict: Not intended for students who have already taken a 300 or 400-level course in German.

GRMN 206.name: Culture Through Conversation
GRMN 206.descr: Discussion of topics drawn from contemporary German life. Designed to broaden knowledge of German culture while impro ving oral and aural language skills.

GRMN 208.name: Contemporary Germany I
GRMN 208.descr: An introduction to contemporary Germany, its culture, its people, their way of life and the issues confronting them.
GRMN 208.restrict: Taught abroad only, in both English and German. Not for major credit. Does not satisfy foreign language requirement.
GRMN 208.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

GRMN 210.name: German for Everyday Life
GRMN 210.descr: Expand your German vocabulary and ability to talk about aspects of daily life with greater fluency. Frequent use of German videos and authentic materials will also increase your aural proficiency and knowledge of German culture. Oral presentations and the creation of your own videos will develop your ability to communicate with others about day-to-day situations such as shopping, travel, ordering in restaurants, giving directions, and using social media.

GRMN 211.name: German Reading and Writing
GRMN 211.descr: Reading and discussion of 20th-century German short stories and novellas. Several short compositions. Grammar review where appropriate.
GRMN 211.restrict: Not intended for students who have already taken a 300 or 400-level course in German.
GRMN 211.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

GRMN 235.name: German Popular Culture
GRMN 235.descr: Examines aspects of German popular culture, especially youth culture: customs, attitudes, pastimes, audio, print and visual media preferred by German young adults. Students exposed to colloquial German used within everyday contexts.
GRMN 235.restrict: Not intended for students who have already taken a 300- or 400-level course in German.

GRMN 246.name: German Youth Culture
GRMN 246.descr: Aspects of German youth culture, including customs, attitudes, and pastimes preferred by students in Germany. Focus on reading, writing, and audiovisual media. Topics include fashion, sports, socialization represented in variety of media, such as TV, film and print media. Taught in German.
GRMN 246.restrict: Not intended for students who have already taken a 300 or 400 level course in German.

GRMN 255.name: Germany in the News
GRMN 255.descr: Explores topics in contemporary German society, culture and politics as expressed in the news media. Emphasis on current events and issues of Germany. Focus of study is the German press: newspapers and magazines printed in the German language.
GRMN 255.restrict: Not intended for students who have already taken a 300- or 400-level course in German.
GRMN 255.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

GRMN 256.name: Reading for Cultural Awareness
GRMN 256.descr: Introduction to German-speaking people’s world view and way of life. Emphasis on reading and discussing a variety of short texts, with opportunities to fine-tune selected aspects of elementary/intermediate grammar.

GRMN 306.name: Practical Oral/Written Expression
GRMN 306.descr: Strengthens grammar and vocabulary skills in preparation for advanced courses. Class exercises include oral exposes, discussion of articles and videos, textual analysis and compositions.

GRMN 307.name: Contemporary Austria
GRMN 307.descr: Introduction to contemporary Austria, its people, their way of life, and the issues confronting them.
GRMN 307.preReq: Any two 200-level courses taught in the German language.
GRMN 307.restrict: Taught abroad only. Taught in German.

GRMN 311.name: Introduction to Modern German Literature
GRMN 311.descr: Masterpieces of poetry, narrative prose, and drama from the 18th century to the present.
GRMN 311.breadth: University: ; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

GRMN 325.name: German Civilization and Culture
GRMN 325.descr: A survey of the major cultural, social, and political developments in Germany from the mid-18th century to the present.
GRMN 325.breadth: University: ; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

GRMN 326.name: The 20th Century in Film
GRMN 326.descr: Survey of the major German cultural and historical events of the 20th century as portrayed in German feature films. Course is taught in German.
GRMN 326.preReq: Any two German courses at the 200-level.
GRMN 326.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S:

GRMN 355.name: Special Topics
GRMN 355.descr: Explores an area of special interest in German literature or culture studies. See http://primus.nss.udel.edu/CoursesSearch/ for topics.
GRMN 355.restrict: May be repeated for credit three times when topics vary.

GRMN 406.name: Advanced German Language
GRMN 406.descr: Grammatical structure and stylistics with special attention given to technical vocabulary and discourse, e.g., business, law, science and agriculture.
GRMN 406.preReq: Two 300-level German courses, one of which may be taken concurrently with the 400-level course.

GRMN 422.name: Age of Goethe
GRMN 422.descr: Major works by Lessing, Lenz, Goethe, Schiller, and their contemporaries. The importance of the Enlightenment, the Storm and Stress movement, the Classical period, and early Romanticism.
GRMN 422.preReq: Two 300-level German courses, one of which may be taken concurrently with the 400-level course.

GRMN 433.name: Nineteenth-Century German Literature
GRMN 433.descr: Studies major literary trends and figures from the end of Romanticism to Naturalism.
GRMN 433.preReq: Two 300-level German courses, one of which may be taken concurrently with the 400-level course.

GRMN 442.name: From Naturalism to Expressionism
GRMN 442.descr: Main literary currents from the 1880’s to the 1920’s.
GRMN 442.preReq: Two 300-level German courses, one of which may be taken concurrently with the 400-level course.

GRMN 453.name: German Literature: 1945 to 1989
GRMN 453.descr: Major authors and literary movements from the end of World War II until German unification.
GRMN 453.preReq: Two 300-level German courses, one of which may be taken concurrently with the 400-level course.

GRMN 455.name: Selected Authors, Works and Themes
GRMN 455.descr: Works of one or more outstanding authors or a special theme.
GRMN 455.preReq: Two 300-level German courses, one of which may be taken concurrently with the 400-level course.
GRMN 455.restrict: May be repeated for credit three times when topics vary.

GRMN 465.name: Postwall Germany: Literature and Culture
GRMN 465.descr: Explores reunited Germany’s cultural and literary landscape and examines how reunification has affected East and West Germans. Focuses on how reunification has (re) shaped German national identity, affected the way Germans remember the past, and contributed to the formation of a multicultural society.
GRMN 465.preReq: Two 300-level German courses, one of which may be taken concurrently with the 400-level course.

GREK 101.name: Elementary Ancient Greek I
GREK 101.descr: Prepares students to read ancient Greek literary works in the original language. Emphasizes building a basic vocabulary and acquiring essential grammar. Includes discussion of ancient Greek culture and civilization.

GREK 201.name: Ancient Prose: Intermediate Greek
GREK 201.descr: Focuses on the works of one or more prose authors with particular attention to review of grammar and syntax. Readings will be drawn from the philosophical, historical, and oratorical works of authors such as Plato, Herodotus, Xenophon, Lysias, Demosthenes, and Isocrates in rotation or in combination.

GREK 202.name: Ancient Poetry: Intermediate Greek
GREK 202.descr: Focuses on the works of one or more poets. Readings will be drawn from the epic, lyric, and dramatic (tragic and comic) works of authors such as Homer, Sappho, Pindar, Aeschylus, Sophocles, Euripides, and Aristophanes in rotation or in combination.
GREK 202.restrict: Satisfies College of Arts and Sciences language requirement.

GREK 301.name: Ancient Prose: Advanced Intermediate Greek
GREK 301.descr: Focuses on the works (in the original language) of one or more prose authors with particular attention to interpretative issues such as themes and contemporary intellectual and cultural milieu. Readings drawn from the philosophical, historical, and oratorical works of authors such as Plato, Herodotus, Xenophon, Lysias, Demosthenes, and Isocrates in rotation or in combination.
GREK 301.preReq: GREK 202 or equivalent. May be repeated for credit four times.
GREK 301.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

GREK 302.name: Ancient Poetry: Advanced Intermediate Greek
GREK 302.descr: Advanced intermediate level course in ancient Greek focusing on the works (in the original language) of one or more poets. Readings will be drawn from the epic, lyric, and dramatic (tragic and comic) works of authors such as Homer, Sappho, Pindar, Aeschylus, Sophocles, Euripides, and Aristophanes in rotation or in combination.
GREK 302.preReq: GREK 202 or equivalent. May be repeated for credit four times.
GREK 302.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

HLPR 211.name: Introduction to Public Health
HLPR 211.descr: Overview of public health, addressing the history, epidemiological principles, social and behavioral factors, and environmental, political and medical-care issues concerning public health practice. Exploration of the practicality of public health as portrayed through current events, guest speakers, and case studies.
HLPR 211.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

HLPR 222.name: Introduction to Epidemiology
HLPR 222.descr: Introduces the basic concepts of epidemiology as applied to public health problems. Particular emphasis is placed on measures of disease frequency, study design and measures of association, as well as the use of epidemiological concepts and methods in addressing public health issues.
HLPR 222.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S:

HLPR 233.name: Introduction to Global Health
HLPR 233.descr: Introduces key diseases and conditions which affect the health of different populations including basic biological and varying social aspects which cause major global health issues. Emphasis on the developing world, the health of the poor, and possible solutions.
HLPR 233.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

HLPR 410.name: Public Health in Practice
HLPR 410.descr: Examine the factors that lead to health inequities (i.e. educational and economic disadvantage, food insecurity, trauma, and isolation). Through cases and presentations, the dilemma confronting policymakers, providers, and community members will be explored. Exposure to community engagement that promote and advance healthy communities.

HLPR 430.name: Behavior Change Strategies and Tactics
HLPR 430.descr: Development of skills to assist individuals in making health behavior changes including weight management, physical activity, medication compliance, tobacco use, and stress management.  This course will assist students in developing plans and courses of action to assist individuals in making health behavior changes.

HDES 101.name: Introduction to Wearable Materials in Health Design
HDES 101.descr: Overview of the structure of materials and their physical, mechanical, and chemical characteristics and properties. Emphasis on materials used for wearable applications.

HDES 110.name: Introduction to Prototyping in Health Design
HDES 110.descr: The purpose of this course is to introduce students to the fundamentals of prototyping wearables.  Students will be exposed to designing for the human body, including fit, comfort, and the metrics for solving functional design research problems.  Students will learn the basics of physical prototyping for the body.

HDES 201.name: Wearable Materials in Health Design
HDES 201.descr: In-depth lectures, discussion, and demonstrations of specific categories of materials used for wearables, led by faculty & guest speakers.

HDES 220.name: Design Toolbox I in Health Design
HDES 220.descr: In-depth lectures, discussion, and demonstrations of specific types of applied design processes and tools for physical prototyping used for health related wearables, led by guest speakers.

HDES 221.name: Design Toolbox II in Health Design
HDES 221.descr: In-depth lectures, discussions and demonstrations of specific types of applied design processes used for health-related wearables, led by guest speakers and faculty

HDES 310.name: Prototyping I in Health Design
HDES 310.descr: Overview and applied learning of prototyping techniques for 3D building of wearable electronics.

HDES 311.name: Prototyping II in Health Design
HDES 311.descr: This course will teach students how to explore a design problem and apply a wearable solution using mixed materials.

HDES 320.name: Mixed Methods Research for Health in Health Design
HDES 320.descr: This course teaches students a user-centered mixed methods research approach to research design, data collection, and data analysis specific to health sciences.

HDES 410.name: Advanced Prototyping in Health Design
HDES 410.descr: Students will design and prototype a mixed-material wearable for an open-ended design challenge.

HLTH 214.name: Introduction to Interprofessional Education & Practice
HLTH 214.descr: Designed to provide students interested in pursuing a career in the health and social care professions with introductory knowledge of interprofessional education and team-based, collaborative, patient-centered care within an evolving health care system.  This is a foundation course for future interprofessional study of health promotion, issues of health care delivery, evidence-based practice, and clinical application of these concepts.

HLTH 215.name: Healthcare Communication:UDSP
HLTH 215.descr: Nursing and Theater course where students will learn to be standardized patients and patient family members. Students will then be used in mock real life scenarios to assess the medical and communication skills of student health care providers.
HLTH 215.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

HLTH 241.name: Ethical Aspects of Healthcare
HLTH 241.descr: Study of basic ethical thought and principles and their application to selected contemporary issues in healthcare.
HLTH 241.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

HLTH 245.name: Cultural Awareness for Health and Healthcare
HLTH 245.descr: The overarching goal of this course is to increase the cross-cultural awareness, knowledge and skills of students so they can better serve and interact with diverse populations in healthcare settings.

HLTH 314.name: Advanced Healthcare Theatre Communication
HLTH 314.descr: Healthcare and Theatre course where students who have completed HLTH 215/THEA 215 will learn to provide quality assurance for simulations in the areas of standardization, feedback, and SP Standards of Best Practice.
HLTH 314.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

HLTH 315.name: Global Health and Healthcare
HLTH 315.descr: This course provides an in depth understanding of contemporary global health and healthcare issues through examining lifestyles of populations, environments, political, and economic influences in diverse nations.
HLTH 315.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S:

HLTH 320.name: Chronic Illness in America
HLTH 320.descr: Interdisciplinary perspective on current health care issues for individuals with chronic illness, including development of client relationships, disease-specific information, caregiving, resource navigation, and health policy. Service learning component involves providing assistance to chronically ill individuals within the home setting.
HLTH 320.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S:

HLTH 360.name: Entrepreneurship in the Health Sciences
HLTH 360.restrict: Students must be accepted into the First Step program in the College of Health Sciences.

HLTH 395.name: Global Internship in Health Sciences
HLTH 395.descr: Guided experiential learning designed to enhance cultural understanding in global health care settings. Selected issues and problems of the people and healthcare delivery are explored within the global context.

HLTH 411.name: Topics in Health
HLTH 411.descr: Selected issues and problems related to individual or population health. Exploration of some topics may include an experiential component. Variable topics.
HLTH 411.restrict: Can be repeated twice when topics vary.

HLTH 490.name: Clinical Research practicum
HLTH 490.descr: Directed research experience with a clinical population of participants either on- or off-campus.

HLTH 491.name: Care Coordination Practicum
HLTH 491.descr: Supervised experience in which students function as patient navigators, coordinating patient care and connecting patients with available services in a clinical setting either on- or off-campus.

HLTH 492.name: International Healthcare Practicum
HLTH 492.descr: Supervised practicum providing students the opportunity to work in an international patient care setting focusing on family practice/primary care issues from multiple perspectives. Well-defined, discipline-specific responsibilities at the site under the direction of medical/healthcare preceptors. Minimum 115 practicum hours required as well as regular seminars/debriefings.

HLTH 495.name: Health Sciences Practicum
HLTH 495.descr: Directed service learning experience in a health services setting.
HLTH 495.restrict: Restricted to senior health sciences majors.

HEBR 105.name: Hebrew I - Elementary
HEBR 105.descr: Introduction to the Hebrew alphabet and language, and development of basic speaking, listening, reading and writing skills.

HEBR 106.name: Hebrew II - Elementary/Intermediate
HEBR 106.descr: Continuation of Elementary Hebrew. Increasing mastery of the basic skills of speaking, listening, reading, and writing through texts, conversations and songs.
HEBR 106.preReq: HEBR 105. Those with background other than HEBR 105 should see instructor for appropriate placement.

HEBR 107.name: Hebrew III - Intermediate
HEBR 107.descr: Strengthening grammar skills, continued practice in speaking, listening, writing and reading through conversation, texts and songs.
HEBR 107.preReq: HEBR 106. Those with background other than HEBR 106 should see instructor for appropriate placement
HEBR 107.restrict: Satisfies College of Arts and Sciences language requirement.

HEBR 205.name: Hebrew Conversation
HEBR 205.descr: Practical use of Hebrew by means of discussions and oral reports on a variety of topics including family, school and work life. Emphasis on improvement of conversational skills for social situations, as well as grammatical competence and reading comprehension through multicultural themes including the revival of the Hebrew language and various issues related to Hebrew culture.

HEBR 208.name: Tel Aviv and Jerusalem Through Time
HEBR 208.descr: A cultural comparison of Tel Aviv and Jerusalem. Tel Aviv and Jerusalem represent different aspects and faces of Israeli society. Our exploration of the two cities will unravel the histories of these cities, while at the same time, look at their present structural, cultural, and social components.
HEBR 208.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HEBR 209.name: Contemporary Israel through Film
HEBR 209.descr: Development of oral and written proficiency in Hebrew through discussion and analysis of Israeli films pertaining to major issues in the development of the young state. Grammar review where needed.
HEBR 209.preReq: HEBR 107 or one 200-level Hebrew course or professor’s permission.
HEBR 209.restrict: Minimum grade of A- required for HEBR 107 and minimum grade of B required for a 200-level course. .
HEBR 209.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 101.name: Europe and the World to 1648
HIST 101.descr: Europe from the ancient Near East to the Age of Discoveries. Social, cultural, and economic interactions within Europe and with the wider world through religion, conquest, and trade.
HIST 101.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 102.name: Europe and the World since 1648
HIST 102.descr: The transformations of Europe since the middle of the 17th century through cultural, social, and economic developments, revolutions, wars, and interactions with other parts of the world.
HIST 102.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 103.name: World History to 1400
HIST 103.descr: The course explores principal political, economic, cultural and social developments in world history as they relate to the present. Start and end dates (along with geographic emphasis on Asia, Africa, the Americas and Europe) vary by instructor.
HIST 103.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 104.name: World History since 1400
HIST 104.descr: The course explores principal political, economic, cultural and social developments in world history as they relate to the present. Start and end dates (along with geographic emphasis on Asia, Africa, the Americas and Europe) vary by instructor.
HIST 104.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 105.name: U.S. History to 1865
HIST 105.descr: An introductory survey of 17th, 18th, and 19th-century American history. Themes and approach vary with the instructor.
HIST 105.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 106.name: U.S. History Since 1865
HIST 106.descr: An introductory survey of American history since 1865. Themes and approach vary with the instructor.
HIST 106.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 130.name: Islamic Near East: 600-1500
HIST 130.descr: Introduces the origins of Islam, its development as a religion and a culture, and the broad trends in Middle Eastern history until 1500.
HIST 130.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 131.name: Islamic Near East: 1500-Present
HIST 131.descr: Considers the traditional make-up of the Middle East and charts the emergence of the region in its present form through the 19th and 20th centuries.
HIST 131.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 134.name: History of Africa
HIST 134.descr: Introduction to African history south of the Sahara, from the earliest times to 1914. Introduces major themes in African history: pre-colonial African political, social and economic institutions; diversity in African political organizations; slave trade and colonialism.
HIST 134.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 135.name: Introduction to Latin American History
HIST 135.descr: Introduction to Latin American history from preconquest period to present.
HIST 135.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 136.name: Topics in East Asia in Film
HIST 136.descr: Explores East Asian cinema and society via readings, discussion and viewing of films by and/or about East Asians. Topics vary.
HIST 136.restrict: May be repeated for credit when topics vary.
HIST 136.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 137.name: East Asian Civilization: China
HIST 137.descr: A survey of major aspects of Chinese civilization, relating the past to the present.
HIST 137.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 138.name: East Asian Civilization: Japan
HIST 138.descr: A survey of major aspects of Japanese civilization, relating the past to the present.
HIST 138.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 139.name: Introduction to Indian Civilization
HIST 139.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change (HIST & CLT); A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 140.name: History of Modern Asia
HIST 140.descr: Comparative survey of the modern histories of China, Japan, and Vietnam, emphasizing their mutual influences and interactions as they responded to the promises and perils of modernity. Topics include traditional societies, imperialism and colonialism, nationalist and communist movements, militarism, the Pacific War, the Vietnam Conflict, and emergence of the Chinese economic powerhouse.
HIST 140.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 145.name: Gandhi’s India
HIST 145.descr: Introduction to Mohandas Gandhi’s profound contribution to India’s independence; to his strategies for peaceful struggle and to his criticism of “modern society”. Other prominent leaders and organizations that held radically different views about modern India will be examined.
HIST 145.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 146.name: Introduction to Jewish Culture and History
HIST 146.descr: Focus on Jewish history from the Biblical period to the present. Study the origins of a group of people who call themselves, and whom others call, Jews. Focus on place, movement, power/powerlessness, gender, and the question of how to define Jews over time and place. Explores Jews as a group of people bound together by a particular set of laws; looks at their dispersion and diversity; explores Jews’ interactions with surrounding cultures and societies; introduces the basic library of Jews; sees how Jews relate to political power.
HIST 146.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 150.name: Great Ideas
HIST 150.descr: Explores the great questions of human history. It juxtaposes East with West and global North with the South as it examines how people have built up–and torn down–human civilization over time.
HIST 150.restrict: May be repeated one time for credit.
HIST 150.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 152.name: American Apocalypse: The Civil War
HIST 152.descr: American Apocalypse explores the causes, character, and consequences of the Civil War. We will begin by investigating the deepening estrangement of North and South in the 1830s and 1840s and the pivotal role played by slavery in that process of alienation. Our attention turns next to the decade of the 1850s and the series of crises that propelled the South toward secession in 1861. A consideration of the fighting itself and the impact of military conflict on the Confederate and Union homefronts will follow.
HIST 152.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 156.name: American Sexualities
HIST 156.descr: Sexuality surrounds us, shapes our culture, and informs our political debates, yet it’s too rarely the topic of informed conversation. This class will give you the opportunity to learn about the history of American sexuality between 1600 and 2016 and gain an appreciation for its importance to our politics and culture today. We will examine a variety of topics: the history of marriage and the family, pregnancy and childbirth, contraception, abortion, sexual assault and harassment, prostitution, erotica/pornography, sexual reform and “social purity” movements, sexuality and racial conflicts, trans*, same-sex desires and communities, the sexual politics of women’s emancipation, and the gay rights movement. You will leave this class better informed and empowered to contribute meaningfully to the ongoing American conversation about sexuality.
HIST 156.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 158.name: Declaring Independence: The Private Lives & Tumultuous Times of America’s Founders
HIST 158.descr: An introduction to the history of the early republic, an inquiry framed by the lives and times of the Founders.
HIST 158.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 170.name: Plagues and Peoples in Human History
HIST 170.descr: Death stalks us all. Using William McNeill’s classic “Plagues and Peoples in History,” this course will examine and effects of major epidemics and diseases in human history (e.g., plague, smallpox, measles, typhuis, AIDS, and the like), including how both professionals and ordinary people sought to explain and deal with these rampaging maladies.
HIST 170.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 178.name: The World on a Ship, 1500-1800
HIST 178.descr: Introduction to a wide variety of cultures and economies during the era of Europe’s empire-building, the rise of the slave trade, the blending of peoples in the western hemisphere, the transformation of consuming and producing patterns across the entire Atlantic world, and more.  Trace the origins, rise, and revolutionary eras of these empires and the indigenous peoples whom these empires transformed.
HIST 178.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 180.name: Revolutions and Social Justice
HIST 180.descr: What is good government?  What is freedom? What is equal opportunity? When is revolution justified?  This course examines the struggle to attain social and political justice in the modern era, from seventeenth-century civil wars to current struggles over economic inequity, civic rights, and political power.
HIST 180.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 190.name: History of the Future
HIST 190.descr: How have scientists, engineers, and technological visionaries imagined the future?  How do films and other forms of popular culture, such as comic books, fiction, and television, reveal society’s hopes and anxieties about those visions?  Weekly film showings, lectures, readings, and other class activities to explore these fascinating questions.
HIST 190.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 200.name: The History of Delaware (1609-2000)
HIST 200.descr: In this course we explore the history of the First State from the time of European contact to the end of the 20th century. Particular attention is paid to slavery and civil rights, political, economic, and social history, and key roles that Delaware played in the nation’s history. The course features lectures and discussion of assigned reading materials.
HIST 200.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

HIST 201.name: Introduction to Global Islam
HIST 201.descr: Introduction to theology, philosophy and history of Islam. Provides basic introduction to Quran, Traditions of Prophet Muhammad, and fundamentals of Islam law and jurisprudence. Explores different interpretations and manifestations of Islam, both historically and contemporaneously. Surveys rapid globalization of Islam and Muslim communities.
